thus able to be the valley of the world.
As the valley of the world—
a metaphor for the sea.
The sea contains all things,
revealing that one’s constant virtue never departs
from the marvelous form of *my* body,
returning to the *infant*.

Knowing the marvelous form of heaven, earth, and all things,
one holds to the *black* without the heart of flaunting the *white*,
thus able to be the model of the world.
As the model of the world—
a metaphor for *embracing unity*.
Unity can gather all things,
revealing that one’s constant virtue does not overreach
the marvelous form of heaven, earth, and all things,
returning to the *Non-Extreme*.

Knowing the marvelous form of the Dao,
one holds to the *humiliated* without the heart of coveting the *honored*.
To hold to the *humiliated*—
to hold to the lowly.
Thus able to be the basin of the world.
As the basin of the world—
a metaphor for deep, bottomless valleys.
When the first *yang* stirs,
the root of primordial *qi* lies therein.
This is where one’s constant virtue is complete
in the marvelous form of the Dao,
returning to the *Uncarved*.
The *Uncarved* disperses into things below—
the divine vessels of the world.
When the Sage uses them,
they become officials and leaders,
thus able to govern the world greatly,
without causing harm or injury.

The *Classic* states:
*"Those who would take the world and act upon it—
I see that they will not succeed.
The divine vessels of the world cannot be seized.
To act upon them is to ruin them;
to grasp them is to lose them.
Thus, things sometimes move or follow,
sometimes warm or cool,
sometimes strong or weak,
sometimes bear or collapse.
Therefore, the Sage avoids excess,
avoids extravagance,
avoids extravagance."*

*The Original Meaning* states:
The Sage sits in the precious position and leads the world,
like the great sea controlling all rivers,
listening as they flow toward their tributaries.
If one harbors the intent to take,
then the rivers dry up,
and those flowing toward tributaries cease—
the sea’s exhaustion awaits.
To sit in the precious position yet harbor the intent to take the world,
and to amass—
is this not like the sea drying up rivers
and cutting off their flow toward tributaries?
I see that they will not succeed is clear.

The divine vessels of the world—
the precious position of emperors and kings.
Life depends on it.
It cannot be achieved by cleverness,
nor seized by force.
To act upon it is to ruin it;
to grasp it is to lose it.
Thus, things sometimes move or follow,
sometimes warm or cool,
sometimes strong or weak,
sometimes bear or collapse.
The *things* referred to—
the divine vessels mentioned earlier—
are what the world relies upon,
and cannot be treated as one’s own possessions.
*Following* means migration.
*Warming/cooling* means praise and blame.
*Strong/weak* means prosperity and decline.
*Bearing/collapsing* means safety and peril.
The *sometimes* reflects
that the Way has no constancy,
and the people are to be feared.
Thus, the Sage knows
that safety must have peril,
and avoids excess.
Knows that prosperity must have decline,
and avoids extravagance.
Knows that praise must have blame,
and avoids extravagance.

The *Classic* states:
*"Those who assist rulers with the Dao
do not use force to dominate the world.
Their affairs return naturally—
where the army passes, thorns and brambles grow.
After great armies, there are years of famine.
Thus, the virtuous achieve only what is fitting,
daring not to take by force."*

「Thus, the fruits of action must be reaped without arrogance,
without boasting,
without pride,
and only when unavoidable—
this is the way of reaping fruits without force.

When things reach their peak, they grow old—
this is called *not* the Dao.
Not the Dao means early ruin.

*The Original Meaning* states:
Chapter A: When rulers possess the world,
it is because they have the land.
With the land, there are ancestral altars.
With ancestral altars, there are the people.
The ancestral altars and the people—
these are the sacred tools of the world.
The previous chapter admonished rulers with the Dao,
this chapter warns ministers against using arms.
Ah! The wisdom of the ancient Sage is profound indeed.
Even to not aspire to the world—
this is why he stands as a teacher for a hundred generations.

The Dao of Heaven favors life and abhors killing,
filling the abundant and nourishing the modest,
valuing gentleness and not favoring harshness.
Gentleness brings life,
harshness brings death—
this is the inevitable course of nature.

Thus, the virtuous act only when unavoidable.
When the people of the world are led by the Dao,
the ministers should assist the ruler,
protect the ancestral altars,
and ensure the people’s safety.
If they instead use arms to dominate the world,
they overturn the ancestral altars,
poison the people—
this is even worse.
Moreover, arms have no constant victor,
their consequences return naturally,
and defeat follows swiftly—
how can one not be warned?

If ministers cannot assist their ruler with the Dao,
but instead indulge in reckless warfare,
boast of martial prowess,
and scheme for glory within the state,
then they waste their people through battle.
The people cannot endure,
and if they do not die in war,
they flee and abandon the land.
The calamities of arms are such across the world.
Where the army marches,
plowing and weeding cease,
and thorns and brambles grow.
A hundred *li* of war brings harm to a hundred *li*.
A thousand *li* of war brings harm to a thousand *li*.
After great armies are raised,
without waiting for floods or droughts,
the years become calamitous.
Is this the Dao of a virtuous minister?

The virtuous achieve only what is fitting,
daring not to take by force—
thus, they should carefully examine what they take.

Observe Confucius, when answering Duke Ling’s inquiry about warfare at a sacrificial feast,
and you will know that arms are not to be spoken of lightly.
When answering Zigong’s question about governance,
you will know that arms can be abandoned.
Alas! The Sage Confucius’ concern for the world—
how is it different from the ancient Sage’s?

To reap fruits without arrogance,
without boasting,
without pride,
and only when unavoidable—
this means that when natural reason dictates,
as in what I have spoken,
one must know that it is unavoidable
and proceed accordingly—
only then does one embody the Dao of reaping without force.

When things reach their peak, they grow old—
if ministers, at the height of their power,
do not know when to retreat,
but instead engage in military posturing and political games,
then danger is near.
This is called *not* knowing the Dao,
and not the Dao means early ruin—
how much more so when bows are stored and dogs are slaughtered,
only hastening their own downfall!

How then can they hope to assist the ruler,
bring order to the state,
and achieve peace in the world?
Those who hear this should take heed.

*The Classic* states:
*"Fine arms are ominous instruments,
which things often detest,
so those who follow the Dao do not wield them.
The virtuous should honor the left in peace,
but honor the right in war.
Arms are ominous instruments,
not the tools of the virtuous,
used only when unavoidable.
Serenity and simplicity are supreme.
Victory should not be gloried in—
to glory in it is to delight in killing.
Those who delight in killing cannot aspire to rule the world.
Auspicious matters favor the left,
ominous matters favor the right.
The lesser general is placed on the left,
the supreme general on the right—

When many are killed,
they should be mourned with sorrowful tears.
Victory should be treated as funeral rites."*

*The Original Meaning* says:
*"Bows and arrows have long threatened the world,
and yet the world has always had those who steal them
to defy the Son of Heaven—
this has been so since ancient times.
How can arms not be treated with caution?
Arms are instruments of killing.
Yet they are called 'fine arms'—
there must be those who delight in killing.
Ominous instruments are instruments of harm.
Earlier, they were called sacred tools,
now they are called instruments of harm—
sometimes revered as sacred,
sometimes reviled as ominous—
how can one possess the world
while allowing such conflicting hearts to arise?
Thus, those who follow the Dao do not wield them.
This follows the remaining meaning of the previous chapter,
warning ministers who love to use arms.*

When the world is at peace,
the virtuous in office should value the left.
But when war arises,
they should value the right.
Arms are ominous instruments,
not the tools of the virtuous,
used only when unavoidable.
They should always uphold serenity and simplicity as supreme.

Serenity and simplicity—
the ruler’s teacher seeks to nurture the people,
not to revel in captives and deceit,
nor to harbor treacherous intentions.
Thus, though they may win,
they do not take pride in it.
If they do take pride,
it is because they delight in killing.
Those who delight in killing cannot aspire to rule the world.

Like the Duke of Chu’s Ziyou at Chengpu,
or Jin’s Xianguo at Ji,
all those who wield arms and love war
ultimately cannot achieve their ambitions.

Mencius told King Xiang of Liang:
*"Those who do not delight in killing can unite the world.
Again he said:
The world has no one who does not seek harmony,
how can one who delights in killing
aspire to rule the world?"*

The left is the honored position,
the right is the lowly position.
Auspicious matters favor the left—
this is joyful.
Ominous matters favor the right—
this is sorrowful.
The lesser general is placed on the left,
for he does not bear sole responsibility for killing,
and thus is given an honored position.
The supreme general is placed on the right,
for he holds the power of life and death,
and thus is given a lowly position.
This clearly shows that ominous matters should not be honored.

Alas! When receiving orders from the general,
the general commands the army,
and the ruler’s orders may not always be obeyed.
At such times, how should the ruler’s heart be?
It is perilous.
Thus, the lesser general is placed on the left,
to show the need for caution,
while the supreme general is placed on the right,
to bear the ominous name of war.»

The **Dao** is ever nameless.
The **uncarved block**—though small—
the world dare not enslave.
If lords and kings could guard it well,
all things would come as guests.

Heaven and Earth unite,
and sweet dew descends.
No command from Heaven,
yet all is balanced.
At first, the **Dao** was nameless,
but when names were given,

To know when to stop

Like the **Dao** in the world,
it is akin to streams and valleys
with the great rivers and seas.

The *Original Meaning* says:
The **Dao** is ever nameless—
nameless, hence honored.
The **uncarved block** has no form—
no form, hence vast.
Only by not dwelling in what is honored and vast
does it remain small yet unassailable by the world.
If lords and kings could embody
this nameless honor and formless greatness,
guard it without loss,
they would not need to proclaim their virtue to all under Heaven—
yet the multitude of people and things
would naturally submit.

For lords and kings to the people,
as Heaven and Earth to all things,
this response and that reaction
are governed by one principle.

Observe Heaven and Earth’s weaving and binding,
the union of yin and yang,
and sweet dew descends—
nothing but the **harmony of balance** at work.

That which is balanced without command
shows how all things first divided,
their **spirit-essence and vital qi** allotted,
their beginnings and growth
requiring not a hair’s breadth of human effort.

From the **Dao**’s nameless origin
to the giving of names,
each thing follows its own principle.
Once names are given,
when deeds are done and matters settled,
Heaven knows to halt—
the **Dao** of withdrawal.

The ancients who grasped this
were exalted as emperors or kings.
Those who do not know the **Dao**,
the **Way** is long past—
how much more so
when bows are stored and dogs are boiled,
only hastening their own downfall?

How then could they hope
to aid the sovereign’s rule,
govern the state in order,
and bring peace to the world?
Hearers of this should take warning.

The *Scripture* says:
**"Excellent weapons are not auspicious instruments**—
things may detest them,
so those who follow the **Dao** do not dwell upon them.
The gentleman in peace values the left,
in war values the right.

Weapons are not auspicious instruments,
not the tools of the gentleman,
used only when there is no other choice.
Calm and unassuming is the highest virtue,
to conquer yet not take pleasure in it.

But those who take pleasure in it
delight in killing people.
Those who delight in killing people
cannot hope to prevail in the world.

Auspicious matters favor the left—
this is joyful.
Ominous matters favor the right—
this is sorrowful.
The lesser general is placed on the left,
for he does not bear sole responsibility for killing,
and thus is given an honored position.
The supreme general is placed on the right,
for he holds the power of life and death,
and thus is given a lowly position.
This clearly shows that ominous matters should not be honored.

Alas! When receiving orders from the general,
the general commands the army,
and the ruler’s orders may not always be obeyed.
At such times, how should the ruler’s heart be?
It is perilous.
Thus, the lesser general is placed on the left,
to show the need for caution,
while the supreme general is placed on the right,
to bear the ominous name of war.

The *Scripture* says:
Weapons are treated with funeral rites—
the ominous nature is evident.
When many are slain,
it is mourned with sorrowful weeping.
When victory is won,
it is treated with funeral rites—
is this not something one should endure with reluctance?

If not an enemy state invading us,
yet unrest lingers below,
and one must use force,
it should not be raised lightly.

The ancient kings had a heart
that could not bear to harm others—
thus they governed with a policy
that could not bear to harm others.

The *Scripture* says:

The **uncarved block**—though small—
the world dare not enslave.

all things would come as guests.

The **Dao** in the world is like rivers and valleys to the seas.

*The Original Meaning* says:
The **Dao** is ever nameless—
nameless, hence revered.
The **uncarved block** has no form—
no form, hence vast.
Though it does not dwell in reverence or vastness,
it is small yet none dare enslave it.
If lords and kings could embody this nameless reverence,
this formless vastness,
and guard it without loss,
they would not need to proclaim their virtue to all under heaven—
yet the multitude of people and things would submit as guests.

For lords and kings to the people,
as Heaven and Earth to all things,
this response and that reaction—
they share the same principle.
Observe how Heaven and Earth, in their interplay,
with yin and yang united,
descend sweet dew—
all arising from the **harmony of balance**.
None commands it, yet all is equal.
At first, the **Dao** was nameless,
but when names were given,
one thing, one principle—
names given, deeds accomplished,
Heaven knows when to halt—
the **Way of withdrawal**.

The ancients who grasped this
were **Emperors above** and **Kings below**—
Fuxi and King Wen.
Fuxi attained it as **Emperor**,
drawing the six primordial strokes,
with **Heaven** to the south and **Earth** to the north,
fixing their positions,
and first giving names—
thus the **Emperor’s Way** flourished.
When King Wen attained it as **King**,
the **Dao** was fully realized—
names had been given.
He then composed the eight trigrams of **Later Heaven**,
with **Heaven** withdrawing to the northwest,
**Earth** to the southwest—
Heaven knew when to halt.
To know when to halt
is how one avoids ruin.
Withdrawing at the right time—
what danger could there be?
The **Emperor-King’s** spirit is thus revealed.

The Sage gathers the essence of Heaven and Earth,
clarifying the **uncarved block**,
and for those who would be lords and kings,
explains it in parables and mysteries—
the principles are now fully laid out.
Yet fearing later ages might not grasp its meaning,
he speaks again in closer terms:
*"The **Dao** in the world is like rivers and valleys to the seas."*

This elucidates what was seen earlier:
*"The heroic, about to take the world."*

*The Scripture* says:
He who knows others is wise,
he who knows himself is enlightened.
He who overcomes others has strength,
he who overcomes himself is powerful.
He who knows contentment is rich,
he who perseveres has resolve.
He who does not lose his place endures,
he who dies yet does not perish is long-lived.

*The Original Meaning* says:
Life and death are great matters indeed.
Examined closely,
when one is manifest, they are human;
when hidden, they are spirits and gods.
Manifest, they return to humanity—
no ancient or modern, no wise or foolish—
all the same.
Yet in life,
prosperity and adversity, gain and loss,
cycle like clouds—
emotions shift with circumstances,
as one bows and rises through an age,
like the Creator’s alternating dark and bright,
expanding and contracting—
ever-changing, a myriad forms in a day.
Without the **Dao** to guide them,
who would not stumble and fall?

Thus one must first know self and others,
then can fully respond to the world and engage with things—
the **Way of humanity**,
the **Way of knowing life and death**.

He who knows others is wise,
he who knows himself is enlightened.
By "know," I do not mean knowing their clans or kin,
their achievements or deeds—
only their hearts.
To know another’s heart,
what task could not be accomplished with wisdom?
To know one’s own heart,
what action could not be measured with clarity?

He who overcomes others has strength—
for desire burns fiercely in them.
He who overcomes himself is powerful—
for Heaven’s principle is clear.
He who knows contentment is rich—
for his inner substance is full.
He who perseveres has resolve—
for his body is strong and healthy.
He who does not lose his place endures—
for he abides in the **Middle Way**.
He who dies yet does not perish is long-lived—
for his essence returns whole.

Mortals, in their rise and fall,
their lifespan fixed by transformation,
do not merely possess enduring virtue or great deeds
to prolong this age—
but those who are manifest as human,
hidden as spirits and gods,
seem to vanish yet endure,
unseen yet divine—
truly, the unperishing exists.

*The Scripture* says:
The **Great Dao** flows—
it can be neither grasped nor resisted.
All things rely on it to live,
yet it does not claim credit.
It accomplishes without naming itself.
It nurtures all things yet does not rule—
ever without desire,
it may be called **small**.
All things return to it yet it does not rule—
it may be called **great**.
Thus the Sage never claims greatness,
and so achieves true greatness.

*The Original Meaning* says:
The Sage nurtures the people,
not boasting of achievements or virtue—
for he embodies the **Dao**.
Though the world bears him up without burden,
and he delights in spreading virtue without restraint,
though he does not desire greatness,
it is inevitable.
The **Great Dao** flows—
omnipresent, neither left nor right.
Wherever it goes,
all things rely on it to live,
yet it does not refuse.
Things live because of it—
no refusal, no gratitude.
It accomplishes without claiming credit—
what deeds remain to claim?
It nurtures all things yet does not rule—
what it should nurture, it nurtures—
how could it claim mastery?
Ever without desire,
it may be called **small**—
the ultimate in humility.
All things return to it yet it does not rule—
it may be called **great**.
With no intention to receive,
things come of their own accord.
With no intention to be great,
things grow great of their own accord.
Such is the **Dao** in its essence.
Thus the Sage takes the **Dao** as his heart,
nurtures all the people,
though his deeds and virtues are great,
he never considers himself great—
and so the world submits,
and he achieves true greatness.

I conclude this chapter,
leaning back, savoring in silence,
wandering in spirit to antiquity,
and there I see the **Emperor of Primordial Times**,
his followers like wild deer,
the **Great Uncarved** in its pure simplicity—
still vibrant, as if alive.

*The Scripture* says:
Hold fast to the **Great Symbol**—
the world will come.
Come without harm,
secure and at peace.
Joy and bait—
passengers will stop.
When the **Dao** leaves the mouth,
it is bland, without taste.
To look at it, insufficient to see;
to listen, insufficient to hear;
to use it, inexhaustible.

*The Original Essence* says:
The **Dao** is vast without bounds—
the Sage follows its pattern and embodies it,
to nurture all under Heaven.

The **Four Quarters** and **Eight Barbarians**,
all are embraced with love and nourished,
their needs met without measure—
thus the world comes to him.

When they come, they are unharmed,
settled in peace,
peace brings tranquility,
tranquility brings harmony.

The ancients who practiced this—
**Yellow Emperor** was one.
Observing the **Dao** of Heaven,
holding fast to its ways,
he ruled with ease while all under Heaven was ordered.

Yet what is this "order"?
Joy and bait—
passengers stop when they arrive.
Weapons against rebels
are like joy and bait for travelers:
when guests come, spread music and food to entertain them,
and they will stay—
then depart.

When **Chiyou**’s chaos arose, it must be punished—
weapons were raised.
When **Yandi** returned, he was pardoned—
weapons could then be laid down.

Weapons cannot always be wielded,
nor can they always be governed by ritual.
Drinking wine begins with order,
but ends in disorder.

When harmony reaches its peak,
strange delights arise—
so too with all things:
beginning with sincerity,
ending in vulgarity.
At first, it is simple,
but when complete,
it becomes excessive.
Thus, weapons—
how can one not be wary?

The **Dao** as speech,
when spoken, is bland without taste—
not like joy and bait,
but like the **Great Symbol**.

The **Symbol** has no form,
so it cannot be seen.
The **Symbol** has no sound,
so it cannot be heard.
The Sage follows and applies it—
its use is boundless.

*The Scripture* says:
To seek to nourish,
first stretch it taut.
To seek to weaken,
first strengthen it.
To seek to abandon,
first establish it.
To seek to take,
first give it—
this is called **subtle clarity**.

The soft overcomes the hard.
Fish cannot escape the deep—
a state’s sharp tools
should not be displayed to the people.

*The Original Essence* says:
Day and night alternate in brightness and obscurity,
people and things wax and wane—
the unceasing flow of antiquity and present,
for **Great Transformation** moves through the cosmos.
Some things cannot escape:
spring brings warmth, winter brings cold,
autumn brings coolness, summer brings heat—
their cycles shift without end,
the natural order.

What intent does **Transformation** have?
Thus cold and heat succeed each other,
and the year’s work is complete.
To seek to nourish,
first stretch it taut—
this is **opening and closing**.
To seek to weaken,
first strengthen it—
this is **subtraction and addition**.
To seek to abandon,
first establish it—
this is **negation and affirmation**.
To seek to take,
first give it—
this is **life and death**.
This is the **subtle yet clear** work of **Great Transformation**.

Thus the soft overcomes the hard.
Softness is the nature of **qi**.
Things change and flow.
Hardness is the nature of form.
Things grow strong and then decay.
To know change and flow,
without falling into rigidity or decay—
then victory lies within our grasp.

Fish cannot escape the deep.
Fish are the people,
the deep is the state,
water is the sharp tools.
Sharp tools are wealth and food.
When the deep holds water, fish are secure;
when the state has wealth and food, the people are secure.
Water hidden in the deep—
fish do not flee.
Wealth and food hidden in the world—
the people do not flee.

For a ruler governing a state,
can he display the means of accumulation to the people?
Knowing the flow of **Great Transformation**,
the ebb and flow of fullness and emptiness,
the fixed principles of nature—
then the mind of reckoning
will naturally have no need for excess.
How much more so when the state’s resources
are stored throughout the world,
like water drying in winter and filling in spring—
never lacking—
what need for worry?

*The Scripture* says:
The **Dao** acts without action,
yet nothing remains undone.
If lords and kings could uphold it,
all things would transform of their own accord.
If transformation begins to stir,
I will steady it with the **Unnamed Primordial**.

The **Unnamed Primordial** will also not desire—
not desiring, it remains still,
and the world will align itself.

*The Original Essence* says:
The **Dao** acts without action,
yet nothing remains undone.
The **Dao** has fixed principles:
what should be done and what should not.
Not doing what should not be done,
doing what should be done—
then spring will be spring,
summer will be summer,
yin and yang will not err,
without words, the four seasons proceed.
If things and their **Dao** reverse their nature,
disastrous **qi** arises,
the seasons lose harmony,
and things are harmed.

So too with governance.
If lords and kings embody the **Dao** of governance,
upholding what the ruler should do,
not doing what the ruler should not—
then rulers will be rulers,
ministers will be ministers,
their roles without error.
The ruler need not speak,
and all officials will be correct.
All things will transform of their own accord.

The altars and people—
none will dare overstep their place,
doing what they should,
not doing what they should not.

If imperial virtue falters,
alternative policies arise.
If the ruler fully embodies the **Dao** of rule,
and ministers fully embody the **Dao** of service,
superiors do not oppress inferiors,
inferiors do not overstep superiors—
how could anyone dare defy their will
and not conform to the **Dao**?

If transformation begins to stir,
it means that after transformation,
there is still another desire to act.
The ruler’s path must consider:
*Why does this desire to act arise?*
There must be those who provoke it.
Do not wait for them to act first—
examine what I have not yet done correctly,
return to what is correct,
and steady it with stillness.

Thus, their intentions will naturally dissipate,
their crimes exposed without need for words,
and they will transform of their own accord.
How dare they act again?

This is called:
*I will steady it with the **Unnamed Primordial**.*
The **Unnamed Primordial** will also not desire—
the ruler, ashamed of his virtue,
the people, fearful of his might—
he must also forget speech,
serene as if unaware—
this is called *not desiring*.
Not desiring, he remains still,
and the world will align itself.

The **Dao**’s action without action,
yet nothing remains undone.

If people of this age
were as inert as logs or stones,
only then could they be called "without action"—
how then could anything be done?
