**Volume Four of the *Original Meaning of the Mysterious Dao Classic*:**
**Du Daojian’s High Daoist Teachings on the Path**

The *Classic* says:
*"To govern people and serve Heaven, nothing surpasses frugality (啬).*
*Only frugality is called early cultivation (早服).*
*Early cultivation is called the accumulation of profound virtue (重积德).*
*Profound virtue accumulated—there is nothing it cannot overcome (无不克).*
*Nothing it cannot overcome—its limits are unknown (莫知其极).*
*When its limits are unknown, one can have a realm (有国).*
*The mother of having a realm—this is the Dao of enduring roots and lasting life (长生久视)."*

*The Original Meaning says:*
*"To govern people is to nourish their exterior (外).*
*Knowing what the body should nourish, one knows what people and all things should nourish.*
*To serve Heaven is to nourish the interior (内).*
*Knowing what the heart should nourish, one knows what spirit (精) should nourish.*
*All that Heaven bestows within us—none should be neglected in nourishment.*
*The way of nourishment is none other than *yin* (音).*
*Frugality (啬) is the preservation of love (保爱).*
*Only *yin*—this is called early cultivation (早服).*
*Diligent cultivation is the method of nourishment.*
*Early cultivation is called the accumulation of profound virtue (重积德).*
*Only by diligently cultivating what should be nourished does virtue accumulate deeply (积德斯厚).*
*Profound virtue accumulated—there is nothing it cannot overcome (无不克).*
*Virtue being profound, the functions of inner and outer nourishment are fulfilled.*
*When people receive their nourishment, even the perilous become secure (危者安).*
*When Heaven receives its nourishment, even the subtle becomes manifest (微者明).*
*Nothing it cannot overcome—its limits are unknown (莫知其极).*
*Only the refined and singular (精一) resides therein.*
*When its limits are unknown, thus one can have a realm (有国)—*
*a realm is like the body (国犹身).*
*What the body should nourish, the realm should nourish.*
*The mother of having a realm—this is the Dao of enduring roots and lasting life (长生久视).*
*The mother is the Dao (母，道也).*
*To govern people with Dao—then the realm flourishes (国昌).*
*To serve Heaven with Dao—then the body is at ease (身康).*
*When the realm flourishes and the body is at ease, enduring longevity is preserved (久长可保).*
*This is called the Dao of enduring roots and lasting life (长生久视).*
*The realm’s root is its people (民), the body’s root is the heart (心).*
*Deep roots make the people secure, firm roots make the spirit secure.*
*When the people are secure, the realm cannot fail to endure (无不长).*
*When the spirit is secure, the body cannot fail to last (无不久)."*

*The Laozi’s governance of people and service to Heaven,*
*recorded in prayers to Heaven and seeking life—*
*these are one and the same.*

The *Classic* says:
*"To govern a great realm, treat it as if boiling a small fish (小鲜).*
*One who rules the world with the Dao—its spirits are not formidable (不神).*
*Not that its spirits are not formidable—*
*its spirits do not harm people.*
*Not that its spirits do not harm people—*
*the Sage also does not harm people.*
*When neither harms the other, virtue returns in exchange (德交归)."*

*The Original Meaning says:*
*"To govern a great realm, treat it as if boiling a small fish (小鲜).*
*A small fish (鲜)—a tiny fish.*
*Boiling a tiny fish—disturb it and it disintegrates, overheat it and it disintegrates; there is a middle way (中道).*
*A great realm is one that possesses the world (天下).*
*The people are like the tiny fish.*
*Governance is like the fire—disturb it and it is damaged, overburden it and it is damaged.*
*One who rules the world with the Dao—its spirits are not formidable (不神).*
*Ghosts and spirits—these are the *qi* of Heaven and Earth, the yin and yang forces.*
*Heaven and Earth have ghosts and spirits, just as a realm has ministers and assistants.*
*One who rules the world with the Dao—*
*The Sage does nothing above, the worthy act below.*
*When above and below are not in discord, their Dao is unerring,*
*then yin and yang *qi* do not stray, and calamities do not arise—*
*thus its spirits are not formidable (不神).*
*The harmonizing function is evident:*
*When the sun shines, it shines; when it rains, it rains.*
*People suffer no illness, things bear no blemish.*
*Five grains ripen, and the people thrive.*
*Its spirits also do not harm people (不伤人).*
*Its spirits do not harm people—*
*The Dao is at peace, the times are prosperous, things abound, the people are rich.*
*Below, there are regular tributes; above, there are no oppressive taxes.*
*The Sage also does not harm people (不伤人).*
*Ah! The people are Heaven’s cherished children (赤子),*
*The ruler is Heaven’s eldest child (元子).*
*The eldest is the longest in virtue (善之长).*
*If the eldest does not harm the young, Heaven will surely aid them—*
*this is called neither harming the other, thus virtue returns in exchange (德交归).*
*By this, it is seen that Heaven has no favorites—*
*only virtue does it assist."*

The *Classic* says:
*"A great realm is the confluence (下流), the intersection of the world (天下之交),*
*the world’s intersection is the receptive (牝).*
*The receptive ever conquers the assertive (牡) through stillness (静),*
*and stillness is the lowly (下).*
*Thus, when a great realm humbles itself to a small realm, it takes the small realm.*
*When a small realm humbles itself to a great realm, it takes the great realm.*
*Thus, sometimes one humbles to take, sometimes one humbles and takes.*
*A great realm seeks only to shelter people,*
*A small realm seeks only to submit to service.*
*Both obtain what they desire, thus the great should properly humble itself."*

*The Original Meaning says:*
*"A great realm is the confluence (下流), the intersection of the world (天下之交)—*
*like when Duke Xuan of Qi asked Mencius about the exchange between neighboring realms (交邻国).*
*A great realm to a small realm is like the sea to rivers—*
*when the great is lowly, the small will return to it.*
*Thus, a great realm must practice humility well,*
*then it can communicate with all small realms of the world.*
*It is like the world’s intersection being receptive (牝)—*
*The receptive ever conquers the assertive (牡) through stillness (静),*
*The receptive is lowly through stillness—*
*when a great realm is both humbly lowly and governs with stillness,*
*like the receptive subduing the assertive through stillness,*
*then the small realms will not need to be subdued by force but will return on their own.*
*Thus, when a great realm humbles itself to a small realm, it takes the small realm.*
*Only the virtuous can govern the great to serve the small—*
*thus Tang served Ge, and King Wen served Kunyi.*
*When a small realm humbles itself to a great realm, it takes the great realm.*
*Only the wise can govern the small to serve the great—*
*thus the Great King served the Xirong, and Goujian served Wu."*

「Thus, when a realm humbles itself to take others, yet governs the great to serve the small, it is one who rejoices in the Dao/Way (乐天者).
When a realm humbles itself and yet takes others, yet governs the small to serve the great, it is one who fears the Dao/Way (畏天者).

A great realm seeks only to encompass and nourish (兼畜) all under heaven—
the one who rejoices in the Dao/Way preserves the world.
A small realm seeks only to submit and serve others—
the one who fears the Dao/Way preserves its own land.
Both attain what they desire,
exchanging mutual sustenance (交相养) and finding harmony (得其宜),
like mountains and valleys to grasses and trees (草木),
when they do not sharply distinguish between the high and the low (不锐上丰下),
then they honor the roots while slighting the branches (则重本轻末).
For the great, when they dwell in humility (处下),
the small will find no realm they cannot bear and contain (容载).
When the small flourish and spread their virtue (敷荣),
the great will find no realm that is not abundantly prosperous (富庶).
Thus, the great ought to dwell in humility (为下).

When Confucius saw Laozi,
and afterward Mencius emerged,
was there not one who gained wisdom from what they saw and heard?
The *Classics* say:
*The Dao/Way is the hidden mystery (奥) of all things,*
*a treasure for the virtuous (善人之宝),*
*a safeguard for the unvirtuous (不善人之所保).*
*Fine words can be used to trade (市),*
*noble deeds can elevate a person (加人).*
*Though people may be unvirtuous, why should they be abandoned?*
Thus, when establishing a Son of Heaven (天子) and appointing the Three Exalted Ministers (三公),
even if one offers a jade tablet with four horses,
it is not as valuable as simply sitting and imparting this Dao/Way.
This is why the ancients held this Dao/Way in such esteem—
was it not because seeking it brings reward (有所得),
and possessing it exempts one from blame (有罪以免)?

Thus, it is the most precious for all under heaven.
The *Original Meaning* says:
*The Dao/Way encompasses Heaven and Earth,*
*concealing and nurturing all things,*
*like a household’s inner chambers (阃奥).*
*When the virtuous obtain it, they can make it a treasure for themselves.*
*When the unvirtuous obtain it, they can make it a safeguard for themselves.*
*Fine words can be used to trade,*
*like Yao’s admonition to Shun: “Consider the matter well.”*
*Noble deeds can elevate a person,*
*as when you ascended to the imperial throne (汝陟帝位者).*
*Fine words and noble deeds are the Dao/Way manifested externally (发于外者),*
*yet even these can be used to trade and elevate—*
*how much more so when the Dao/Way is preserved within!*
*Though people may be unvirtuous, why should they be abandoned?*
*The Book of Documents* says:
*“To know people is wisdom (哲),*
*to appoint them properly is governance (官人).*
*To settle the people is benevolence (惠),*
*and the common folk will cherish you (黎民怀之).”*
*If one is wise and benevolent,*
*why fear the treachery of Huan Dou (欢兜),*
*why be exiled by the Youmiao (有苗),*
*why dread the deceitful tongues and pleasing appearances of Gong Ren (孔壬)?*

*Observe Yao’s words “Ah!” and “Alas!” (曰吁曰佛),*
*and the wickedness of the Four Tyrants (四凶) was known*
*even without Shun’s judgment.*
*Yet, when their wickedness was proclaimed (声其不善),*
*Yao did not immediately punish them (不即罪),*
*which shows his imperial virtue (帝德) was broad and far-reaching,*
*his benevolence as vast as Heaven (其仁如天),*
*and he did not lightly take life (不轻杀戮).*

Thus, when establishing a Son of Heaven and appointing the Three Exalted Ministers,
the Son of Heaven acts as father and mother to the people (作民父母),
the Three Exalted Ministers discuss the Dao/Way and govern the realm (论道经邦),
they harmonize (燮) the principles of yin and yang,
assist in the transformation and nurturing of all things (赞化育),
settle the people, and preserve the world.
*The Book of Documents* says:
*“Do not neglect the officials of the people (无旷庶官),*
*for the work of Heaven, let man take its place (天工人其代之).”*
*Beyond this, inspect the four directions (巡四岳),*
*audience the feudal lords (朝诸侯),*
*though one may have the honor of a jade tablet with four horses,*
*or the splendor of a chariot with four horses,*
*these are but external matters (外物),*
*far less valuable than humbling oneself and facing south,*
*sitting to impart this Dao/Way,*
*and letting all under heaven govern itself (自治).*

This is why the ancients held this Dao/Way in such esteem—
was it not for this reason?
It is not merely that seeking it brings reward,
and possessing it exempts one from blame.
Thus, it is the most precious for all under heaven.

When the people are ignorant and misguided (昏垫),
and unfortunately bear the guilt of wickedness (有不善之罪),
then the ruler laments and pities them, saying:
*“I am the one who wronged them.”*
*“Yea” (耶) is an uncertain word.*
*This is not to condone their wickedness,*
*but to recognize that those who carry out punishments (自有司杀者) exist.*
*Thus, he holds the left contract (执左契) and does not blame the people,*
*using this virtue of cherishing life (好生之德)*
*to win the hearts of the people (洽于民心).*
*If one were like Yao, they could be called*
*the most precious for all under heaven and all ages.*

The *Classics* say:
*“To act without action (无为),*
*to govern without governance (无事),*
*to savor without savoring (无味).*
*Great or small, many or few,*
*repay resentment with virtue (报怨以德).*
*Plan for difficulty in its ease (图难於其易),*
*achieve greatness in its smallness (为大於其细).*
*The most difficult matters in the world,*
*must be begun in ease (必作於易).*
*The greatest affairs in the world,*
*must be begun in smallness (必作於细).*
*Thus, the Sage never strives for the great,*
*and so can achieve the great.*

*He who makes light of promises,*
*will be few in his trustworthiness (寡信).*
*He who is prone to change,*
*will encounter many difficulties (多难).*
*Thus, the Sage still finds difficulty,*
*and so never faces difficulty.*

The *Original Meaning* says:
*The aged Sage (老圣) sighed at the corruption of the Dao/Way,*
*that the clever and deceitful (智诈) deceived one another,*
*leading to chaos (为乱),*
*and there was no way to restore the hearts of the people (无以挽回人心).*
*Thus, he expounded the ancient Way of non-action (敷迷上古无为之化),*
*to instruct posterity (诏后世),*
*to turn the shallow and deceptive (锲薄) winds of the age*
*into the pure and thick (淳厚) qi of virtue,*
*and to rely on the Dao/Way.*

*Thus, to act without action is to follow nature (法自然).*
*To govern without governance is to align with Heaven’s principles (顺天理).*
*To savor without savoring is to delight in simplicity (乐恬淡).*
*Great or small, many or few—*
*all are contained within the relations of lord and subject, ruler and common folk (君臣民庶在焉).*
*To repay resentment with virtue,*
*when there is interaction between the high and the low (上下之交),*
*if there is wickedness, then one should repay it with virtue as their heart.*
*As it says: “I treat the good with goodness, and the wicked also with goodness.”*

*Plan for difficulty in its ease,*
*achieve greatness in its smallness—*
*one’s schemes must be cautious from the beginning (谨始),*
*and not allow difficulties to grow unchecked (无使滋蔓难图).*
*The most difficult matters in the world,*
*must be begun in ease (必作於易).*
*The greatest affairs in the world,*
*must be begun in smallness (必作於细).*
*This is the principle of things (物理所在).*
*From the subtle to the manifest (从微至着),*
*like the easy reversals of the *I Ching* (易之不远复),*
*without regret or remorse (无祇悔),*
*from one yang to two yangs (一阳二阳),*
*accumulating to become the *Qian* (乾).*
*Thus, the Sage never strives for the great,*
*and so can achieve the great.*

*The Sage has the virtue of *Qian* (六阳之德),*
*not making themselves great,*
*yet achieving greatness.*

*He who makes light of promises,*
*will be few in his trustworthiness.*
*He who is prone to change,*
*will encounter many difficulties.*
*The hearts of people are shallow and fickle (浇薄),*
*often behaving thus.*
*Few begin with good intentions,*
*fewer still see them through (鲜克有终).*
*Thus, the Sage finds difficulty in the beginning.*
*The Sage’s heart,*
*worries before the world’s worries (先天下之忧而忧),*
*and rejoices after the world’s rejoicings (后天下之乐而乐).*
*This is the one who has both beginning and end (有始有卒).*
*Only because the Sage finds difficulty in the beginning,*
*do they never face difficulty in the end.*

The *Classics* say:
*“Its stability is easy to maintain,*
*its early signs are easy to plan against.*
*Its fragility is easy to shatter,*
*its subtlety is easy to disperse.”*

「To act before things exist,
And govern before chaos arises.
A tree as thick as a man can embrace,
Grows from a tiny sprout.
A nine-tiered terrace,
Rises from a pile of earth.
A journey of a thousand *li*,
Begins beneath one’s feet.

The doer invites ruin,
The grasping one invites loss.
Thus, the Sage acts without doing—no ruin;
Holds without grasping—no loss.

The people’s undertakings,
Often falter as they near completion.
To guard the end as the beginning,
Then no matter will fail.

Therefore, the Sage desires without desiring,
Does not prize hard-to-obtain goods.
Learns without learning,
Reversing the errors of the multitude.
To aid the natural flourishing of all things,
And dare not act.

*The Original Meaning* says:
*“Its stability is easy to maintain,”*
This follows the previous chapter’s intent,
Speaking of the principles of all things under Heaven.
To preserve their completion,
One must be cautious at their outset.
In times of peace and tranquility,
Guard against reckless action—
Then stability is easy to uphold.
Like planning before a matter takes shape,
Breaking what is brittle,
Dispersing what is subtle.

To act before things exist,
Is not to force existence—
This is how to prevent ruin before it begins.
To govern before chaos arises,
Is not to force order—
This is how to settle and restrain before disorder takes hold.

Thus, it is likened to a tree’s growth from a sprout,
A terrace’s rise from a pile of earth,
A journey’s start from one’s feet.
At their beginning, their signs are most faint,
Yet when they reach their end,
The tree is as thick as an embrace,
The terrace stands nine layers high,
The journey spans a thousand *li*.

Is this not the work of many years?
Their beginnings must not be neglected.

In all matters under Heaven,
Once one’s heart turns to action,
Defeat often follows.
To exert force and grasp,
Loss and regret often ensue.
What one undertakes with all one’s strength,
Will later bring misfortune.

Thus, the Sage does without forcing—
No ruin in undertakings.
Does not cling to rigidity—
No loss or regret.

The common people are otherwise.
Their undertakings,
Often falter as they near completion,
For they have not heard the Way of maintaining stability.
To guard the end as the beginning,
Then no matter will fail—
Only the Sage can achieve this.
Therefore, the Sage, like King Wen,
Held two-thirds of the realm under Heaven,
Yet served the Shang dynasty—
This shows their desire without desiring,
Their disregard for hard-to-obtain treasures.

To view the people as wounded,
To gaze upon the Dao yet not see it—
This shows their learning without learning,
Reversing the errors of the multitude.

But to aid the natural flourishing of all things,
And dare not act—
In the end, this is simply non-action.

Thus it is said:
“With King Ji as father,
And King Wu as son,
The Sage without worries—
Is this not King Wen?”

*The Classics* say:
“Ancient masters of the Dao,
Did not enlighten the people,
But rather sought to befuddle them.
The people’s difficulty in governance,
Arises from their excess of cleverness.
Thus, to govern with cleverness,
Is the thief of the state.
To govern without cleverness,
Is the state’s blessing.
Knowing these two truths,
Is the model for governance.
To always know the model,
Is called the Mysterious Virtue.
The Mysterious Virtue is profound and distant,
Opposed to things—
Only then does one reach the Great Harmony.

*The Original Meaning* says:
“Ancient masters of the Dao,
Like Yao’s governance of the world,
Where the people neither recognized nor knew—
Was this not to enlighten them,
But rather to befuddle them?

Why so?
The ruler governed with non-action,
Letting the people follow without knowing—
This was the state’s blessing.
The people’s difficulty in governance,
Came from the ruler’s stimulation of their cleverness.

Man possesses five natures,
All bestowed by Heaven,
None without natural principles,
Just as Heaven has the Five Phases.
Spring nurtures *ren*,
Summer fosters *li*,
Autumn fulfills *yi*,
Winter conceals *zhi*,
And *xin* flows through all four seasons.
Thus, the cold and heat regulate the seasons,
And floods and droughts do not occur,
Defects and diseases do not arise,
And all things flourish.

To govern the people as if holding their fate,
Yet unaware of *ren*’s springing,
*Li*’s growth,
*Yi*’s fulfillment,
And only valuing *zhi*’s concealment—
Then the year is always winter,
And all things are stored yet not born.

Can this be called a year?
A year of constant winter,
And all things stored yet not born—
Governance that favors cleverness,
Is only hoarding and not knowing release.
Can this be called governance?

It is better to have thieving ministers
Than ministers of hoarding.
Thus, to govern with cleverness,
Is to rob one’s people,
And thereby rob one’s state.
To govern without cleverness,
Is to bless one’s people,
And thereby bless one’s state.
Knowing these two truths,
Is the model for governance.
To always know the model,
And not exalt cleverness—
Then blessings extend to the state,
This is called the Mysterious Virtue.

The Mysterious Virtue,
Is to aid the natural flourishing of things,
And not to enlighten the people.
The Mysterious Virtue is profound and distant,
Opposed to things—
This speaks of its difference from governance through cleverness.
To govern without cleverness,
Only then does one reach the Great Harmony.
Great Harmony means all things fulfill their nature of growth and completion.

*The Classics* say:
“Rivers and seas become kings of all valleys
Because they excel in yielding.
Thus, the Sage desires to be above others,
By speaking from below.
To be first among others,
By placing themselves last.
Thus, the Sage, though in high position,
Does not burden the people,
Though in front,
Does not harm the people.
Thus, all under Heaven gladly follow,
And never tire—
Because they do not contend,
No one under Heaven can contend with them.

*The Original Meaning* says:
“Rivers and seas become kings of all valleys
Because they excel in yielding.
This ties together the meaning of the previous chapters.
Rivers and seas excel in yielding,
Thus they become kings of all valleys.
Therefore, the Sage follows the Way of yielding,
And does not desire to be above others.
Yet, when necessity compels them to be above others,
They say:
‘To desire to be above others,
By speaking from below.’
Though in high position,
Their words remain humble.”

The Sage does not contend—
Is this not the meaning of *humble reception and benefit*?

Though their name may come first,
Their person follows behind.
Yet there are those who push forward and take precedence.
Only because they can yield and follow,
The Sage, though in high position, does not burden the people—
Not because they seek to exalt themselves.
Though in front, they do not harm the people—
Not because they seek to obstruct others.
Only because they do not burden or harm,
All under Heaven gladly follow without tiring of their being above or first.

Why is this?
Because they do not contend with the people for high position or precedence,
Thus no one under Heaven can bear to contend with them.

*The Mysterious Classic* states:
When speaking of cultivating oneself,
The governance of family and state is included.
When speaking of governing the state and family,
Cultivating oneself is included.
The wise observer will surely grasp the deeper meaning beyond the words.

*The Classic* says:
All under Heaven say my Dao is vast yet seems unworthy.
Only because it is vast does it seem unworthy.
If it were worthy for long, it would be trifling.
I possess three treasures; I guard and hold them:
First, *compassion*;
Second, *frugality*;
Third, *not daring to be first under Heaven*.

Compassion makes one courageous.
Frugality makes one abundant.
Not daring to be first under Heaven makes one a vessel of excellence and leader.

Now they abandon compassion and seek courage,
Abandon frugality and seek abundance,
Abandon yielding and seek precedence—
They are doomed.

Compassion means victory in war and steadfastness in defense.
Heaven aids them, shielding them with compassion.

*The Original Meaning* says:
The Sage’s Dao is not the *Wuwei* of ancient antiquity,
Nor the harmonious Way of Tang and Yu.
Its greatness is formless—
It cannot be sought through names or speech.
Few common people recognize it,
Thus it is said: *All under Heaven say my Dao is vast yet seems unworthy.*
Meaning it is beyond comparison.

Only because it is vast does it seem unworthy.
If it were worthy for long, it would be trifling—
Self-explanatory words, like saying:
*Only Heaven is great; only Yao followed it—*
Who could truly emulate it?

As for Yu’s leveling the earth and completing Heaven’s work,
That can be traced and followed.

The Sage laments that all under Heaven say my Dao is vast yet seems unworthy,
So he further explains the lesser aspects:
I have three treasures; I guard and hold them.
Guard and hold means to cherish and preserve them.
First, *compassion*—not daring to slaughter Heaven’s people wantonly.
Second, *frugality*—not daring to waste Heaven’s resources recklessly.
Third, *not daring to be first under Heaven*—not daring to initiate Heaven’s punishments.

Compassion makes one courageous—
Returning victorious, the troops dance with dry reeds, and the people rally.
Frugality makes one abundant—
Wearing simple garments to honor the spirits,
Building low halls to invest in canals and dikes.
Not daring to be first under Heaven makes one a vessel of excellence and leader.

Shun appointed Zongzhen as his teacher, then promoted Gao Yao,
Saying: *“Let me abdicate.”*
The ministers refused, so he yielded.
Thus, the ancients who practiced this were like Yu.

Now they abandon compassion and seek courage—
Thus they slaughtered Long Fang and Bi Gan.
Abandon frugality and seek abundance—
Thus they built tilted palaces of jade and yew,
Chambers of gemstone and pearl gates.
Abandon yielding and seek precedence—
Thus they imprisoned Tang on the Southern Mound and at Youli,
And met their doom at Nanhuo and Muyewild.
The ancients who practiced this were like Jie and Zhou.

Compassion means victory in war—
The benevolent are invincible—
And steadfastness in defense.
The people would die for them without hesitation.
Heaven aids them, shielding them with compassion.
Thus they escaped the calamities of the Southern Mound and Youli.
The ancients who practiced this were like Tang and Wen.

When Tang overthrew Jie, he said:
*“In ancient Xia, the rulers and their successors flourished in virtue,
And there were no Heavenly calamities.
Mountains, rivers, ghosts, and spirits—
All were at peace.
Even birds, beasts, fish, and tortoises thrived.
But their descendants did not follow this.
Heaven sent disaster,
And entrusted it to me by decree.”*

When Zhou attacked Zhou, they said:
*“Only the wicked have no remorse.
They dwell in arrogance,
Do not sacrifice to Heaven or the spirits,
And abandon their ancestral temples.
The crimes of Shang are complete—
Heaven’s mandate punishes them.”*

This is what is meant by *worthy*.
Tang and Wu could not be the rulers of Yao and Shun—
Their lesser status is clear.

*The Classic* says:
The skilled warrior does not rely on force,
The skilled fighter does not rage,
The skilled victor does not contend,
The skilled leader serves below.

This is called the *virtue of non-contention*,
This is called the *power of using people*,
This is called *harmonizing with Heaven*—
The ultimate of the ancients.

*The Original Meaning* says:
The ancients skilled in being a warrior did not rely on force—
Was it not Wen Wang?
Imprisoned at Youli, he was betrayed by Chonghou Hu.
Wen Wang received the Mandate,
And after six years, he attacked Chong.
The skilled fighter does not rage—
Chonghou Hu advised Zhou,
Who offered the western lands of Luo and red-soil fields a thousand *li* to Zhou,
Asked to abolish the *pao-lao* torture,
And was granted bows, arrows, axes, and iron,
Thus gaining control over military campaigns as *Xiber*,
Overseeing the southern states of Jiang, Han, and Ru,
And the surrounding vassals.

The skilled victor does not contend—
Lü Shang, a man from the Eastern Sea,
Met over seventy rulers without being heard,
And people called him a madman.
Fishing at Weiyang,
Xiber labored and questioned him:
*“Do you take pleasure in fishing?”*
Lü Shang replied:
*“The noble takes pleasure in their aspirations,
The petty in their deeds.
I fish not for pleasure.”*
Xiber spoke with him and was greatly delighted,
Saying: *“My ancestor, Taigong, has long awaited you.”*
Thus he was called *Taigong Wang*,
And appointed as teacher.

The skilled leader serves below—
As in the *Four Virtues* described above—
This is called the *virtue of non-contention*,
This is called the *power of using people*,
This is called *harmonizing with Heaven*—
The ultimate of the ancients.

*Harmonizing with Heaven* means:
It is the ultimate standard for rulers.

As for the **Wen Wang**—he was indeed the finest exemplar of a scholar-official in antiquity, worthy of being a model for all under Heaven and future generations.

In days past, **Xī Bó** once asked **Taigong**,
*“The Shang king’s crimes kill the innocent—will you aid me in my distress?”*
Taigong replied:
*“The Dao of Heaven brings no calamity—one must not act first.
The Dao of humanity brings no calamity—one must not plot first.”*

Again he asked:
*“When a ruler’s actions and undertakings invite calamity or divine retribution, how does this manifest?”*
Taigong said:
*“Heavy taxation and lavish palaces bring widespread sickness and pestilence.
Frost and dew destroy the five grains, and silk and hemp fail to mature.
Excessive hunting and fowling, disregarding seasonal prohibitions, bring frequent great winds, and the grains bear no fruit.
Desecrating sacred mountains and damming great rivers brings frequent great floods.
Pursuing warfare without cease brings eclipses of the sun and moon, and the White Star strays from its course.”*

**Xī Bó** said, *“Truly so. Within no more than ten years, Shang perished, and all under Heaven turned to Zhou—this too is the proof of benevolent frugality and not acting first.”*

The **Classic** says:
*“In war, there is a saying: I dare not be the aggressor, but only the defender.
I dare not advance even an inch, but retreat a foot.
This is called *‘having no march’*—
*‘no arms’*—*‘no enemy’*—*‘no weapons.’*
No greater calamity exists than contempt for the enemy—
contempt for the enemy nearly loses my treasure.”*

Thus, when armies clash, the one who first yields will win.

The **Original Meaning** says:
*“Warfare is meant to guard against unforeseen threats, not to threaten all under Heaven.
In war, there is a saying—quoting ancient military doctrine, as follows:
The side that strikes first is the aggressor; the side that responds is the defender.
I dare not be the aggressor, nor dare I strike first to threaten all under Heaven.
But if I am the defender, and the enemy does not provoke me, I must respond only when forced—this is guarding against the unforeseen.
Even when forced to respond, I still dare not advance an inch to contempt the enemy;
rather, I retreat a foot to fortify my defense.
This is called *‘having no march.’*
*March* refers to leading an army—
*‘no march’* means having no aggressive intent, though the army moves, it does not advance lightly.

*‘No arms’*—*‘arms’* means defense—
*‘no arms’* means having no intent to strike, though defending, one does not lightly raise a hand.

*‘No enemy’*—*‘enemy’* means to provoke—
*‘no enemy’* means having no intent to provoke, though engaging in battle, one does not lightly confront the enemy.

*‘No weapons’*—*‘weapons’* are instruments of slaughter—
Though wielding instruments of slaughter, one does not resort to killing.
Why? No greater calamity exists than contempt for the enemy.

The feudal lords treat their states as their hearts—
thus, they cannot always avoid being the first to strike.
The Son of Heaven treats all under Heaven as his heart—
these are my people, those are also my people—
harming them is harming myself.
How could I lightly contempt the enemy?

This is why **Yú** bowed to **Chang’s** words and recalled his armies,
so that the **Miao people** submitted in peace.

Alas, contempt for the enemy nearly loses my treasure—
*‘treasure’* refers to the *three treasures* of the previous chapter:
the true treasure is virtue, and kindness and kinship are the treasures.
Thus, all under Heaven’s people are my treasures.
Therefore, when armies clash, the compassionate will prevail.
For when two armies face each other, if one is moved by pity and spares life,
the hearts of the people will be revealed—
without battle, their armies will yield, and victory is assured.”

This concludes the meaning of the two preceding chapters.
The previous chapter praised **Wen Wang** for his non-martial virtue,
while subtly restraining the intent toward **Wū Wáng**.

The sages, both ancient and modern, often cite warfare,
taking **Yú’s** pacification of the **Miao** as their model.

The **Classic** says:
*“My words are very easy to know,
very easy to practice.
Yet none under Heaven can know them,
none can practice them.
Words have their roots, deeds have their lords.
It is only because of ignorance
that they do not know me.
Few know me—
thus, I am precious.
Therefore, the sage wears coarse cloth while harboring jade.
Some manuscripts read: *‘None know me.’*”*

The **Original Intent** states:
*"Words are the means to bear the Dao.
Knowledge is knowing the Dao; practice is walking the Dao.
Very easy to know, very easy to practice—
I have no hidden meaning for you.
To walk it is to find harmony on all sides,
Yet none under Heaven can know or practice it—
Ah, what a lament!
Words have their roots, deeds have their lords.
Words with roots are all drawn from the ancient texts of *Fen* and *Dian*,
And deeds with lords are all grounded in the Emperor’s Way.
How could this be mere empty speech?
To not know words is to not know the Dao—
Thus, they do not know me.
Since they cannot know, nor can they practice,
Their lack of knowledge is evident.
Only because of ignorance
Are those who know me few—
This is not surprising.
Alas, few know me,
So I am precious—
Or as some say, *‘the law.’*
My Dao is taken from the Dao,
Thus I am precious.

The **Original Intent** says:
Knowledge is knowing the Dao;
Ignorance is not knowing the Dao.
To know while not speaking is exalted;
To speak while not knowing is folly.
Only those who scorn folly
Do so because they are not folly.
The sage is not folly,
Because the sage scorns folly—
Thus, the sage is not folly.
*(The Classic says: To know while not speaking is exalted;
To speak while not knowing is folly.
Only those who scorn folly
Do so because they are not folly.
The sage is not folly,
Because the sage scorns folly—
Thus, the sage is not folly.)*
The **Original Intent** says:
The sage knows without error, acts without error—
Who would regret this?

In ancient Zhou, there stood a bronze man,
With three sealed mouths and inscriptions on his back.
When the sage was in Zhou,
Surely the bronze man was made—
Yet Confucius, upon seeing Zhou,
Had once been deceived by touching it.
The previous chapter said:
‘Very easy to know, very easy to practice—
Yet none under Heaven can know or practice it.’
This chapter speaks of:
‘To know while not speaking is exalted;
To speak while not knowing is folly.’
Does the Dao truly remain unknowable forever?
To know is to know, to not know is to not know—
This is knowing.

The **Classic** says:
*"If the people do not fear punishment,
Then the greatest punishment has arrived.
Do not narrow their dwelling,
Do not weary their birth.
Only because of not wearying
Is it that they do not weary me.
Thus, the sage knows himself but does not reveal himself,
Loves himself but does not exalt himself—
Hence, he discards that and takes this."*

The **Original Intent** says:
Punishment is the law.
The people value their bodies,
Yet when punishment is added—
Who does not know to fear?
Yet there are those who disregard the axe and the blade,
And transgress against it—
Why?
Because the greatest punishment has arrived.
They know they have no escape,
And even the lowly fear suffering—
How much more those of great strength!
Tang left Xia’s net of three sides—
This was well-founded.
The southern lords of Han heard it say:
‘Tang’s virtue extended even to birds and beasts—
Forty states submitted to him.’
Alas, Jie was a ruler,
Tang was a subject.
To comfort me is to be my successor,
To oppress me is to be my enemy—
The heart of the great man,
How could it be narrow?
If narrow, then there are things it cannot contain,
And it monopolizes blessings and imposes punishments—
Reaching everywhere, none can endure.
If the people cannot endure,
Then subjects kill their rulers,
Sons kill their fathers—
Surely there are those it cannot contain.
This is why Jie perished
And Tang rose.
Do not narrow their dwelling—
Their dwelling is the heart.
A heart not narrow is where spirit and clarity reside,
And all things are contained within the Way of life.
Do not weary their birth—
Their birth is both inner spirit and clarity,
And outer people and things—
All must not be weary.
If weary, then the heart will abandon me—
This is the Way of life and death.
Only because of not wearying
Do I not weary them.
Thus, they do not weary me.
The sage knows himself but does not reveal himself—
Without the heart of arrogating others.
Loves himself but does not exalt himself—
Without the heart of threatening others.
Hence, he discards that narrowness and weariness,
And takes this knowing and loving."*

The **Classic** says:
*"Courageous in daring brings death,
Courageous in not daring brings life.
These two paths—
One brings benefit, one brings harm.
What the heavens abhor,
Who knows their cause?
Thus, even the sage finds it difficult.
The Way of Heaven
Conquers without strife,
Responds without words,
Summons without calling.
It is tranquil yet ever-planning.
The Heavenly net is vast and wide,
Though sparse, it does not lose a single thread."*

The **Original Intent** says:
Courage is resolve;
Daring is *qi*.
Resolve reaches its end,
*Qi* follows next.
To hold resolve without unleashing *qi* is the Way of life.
If *qi* is one, then it moves;
If resolve moves and *qi* strays—
Then it is the Way of stumbling and death.
To know these two paths—
One brings benefit, one brings harm,
For resolve and *qi* are two things—
If their Way is mastered, then benefit.
If their Way is lost, then harm.
What the heavens abhor,
Who knows their cause?
This is the origin of abhorrence.
The heavens love life and abhor death—
Who can know the heavenly intent to abhor death
And not defy it?
Thus, even the sage finds it difficult.
The heavenly intent is unfathomable,
Yet the sage still considers it difficult,
And does not act with daring courage.
The Way of Heaven
Conquers without strife—
Softness overcomes hardness.
Responds without words—
Sincerity moves the spirit.

The Way does not summon yet comes of its own accord—
When one does good, a hundred blessings descend;
When one does evil, a hundred calamities descend.

Thus, when one is cautious yet skillful in counsel,
The Dao of Heaven rewards virtue and punishes licentiousness.

The Heavenly Net is vast and open,
Yet nothing escapes its grasp.

Heaven’s will is inscrutable,
Life’s decree is not constant—
If one’s virtue is constant,
One preserves one’s station.
If virtue is not constant,
The Nine Realms bring ruin.

For calamity and blessing have no gate—
Only the self invites them.

When Jie and Zhou ruled as tyrants,
Had they but appointed the worthy and heeded counsel,
Known Heaven’s abhorrence,
And not acted with reckless daring,
Even though they were cautious—
How could the sages Shang and Wu dare not submit?

Alas, how dire!
Was it not that Jie and Zhou brought ruin upon themselves?
Or was it the Heavenly Net’s vastness that never fails?

How the sage’s words cannot be defied!

The *Classic* says:
*"The people do not fear death—
How can you frighten them with death?"*

If one makes death a constant terror,
And those who act strangely are seized and killed—
Who would dare?

Only the proper officers should kill.
To usurp the role of the executioner
Is to usurp the place of the master carpenter in his craft.
To usurp the master carpenter’s chisel—
Few escape uninjured hands.

The *Original Meaning* says:
*"To cherish life and abhor death—
This is the common heart of all."*

The people do not fear death—
How can you frighten them with death?

This follows the previous chapter’s intent,
Lamenting that the Way of the King is not in action—
When the people do not die by war,
They die by famine—
Who kills them?

Yet laws are made strict,
Taxes and levies are multiplied,
The people are coerced by threats,
Driven to their deaths with no escape—
Not that they do not fear death,
But that they cannot avoid it.

Mencius said:
*"To kill with the blade or with governance—
This is the same intent."*

If the people do not fear death,
It means they cannot endure life,
And harbor a heart of equal indifference to death.

If the ruler relaxes laws,
Lightens taxes and labor,
Reduces burdens—
Then the people, each nourished in their place,
Would fear strange actions and unrest.

If the people are properly nourished,
Yet some still cause unrest—
Seize them and kill them as proper officers,
Place them under punishment—
This is Heaven’s killing.

Who dares say the people always fear death,
And dare not transgress?

The proper executioner is Heaven.
To usurp Heaven’s killing is to act as man.
To kill rightly is Heaven’s killing;
To kill wrongly is to kill as man—
How could it not injure?

Like the master carpenter’s craft—
To usurp the master’s chisel,
Few escape uninjured hands.
This illustrates killing by governance—
Truly, it is self-injury.

When the Zhou Dynasty moved east,
Authority fell to the feudal lords,
Who unilaterally waged war—
Like usurping the master’s chisel,
Not only did the proper order collapse,
But the armies of the feudal lords,
Ravaging a thousand *li*,
Slaughtered the people—
They had no time to fear death.

When Heaven’s decree overcame man,
Few did not fail—
This is the meaning of injury to the hands.

The *Classic* says:
*"The people’s hunger comes from their rulers’ excessive taxes—
Thus they hunger.
The people’s difficulty to govern comes from their rulers’ interference—
Thus they are difficult to govern.
The people’s indifference to death comes from their rulers’ excessive pursuit of life—
Thus they treat death lightly."*

Only those who do not cling to life
Are wiser than those who prize it.
The *Original Meaning* says:
*"The state depends on the people as its root,
The people depend on food as their heaven.
A state cannot exist without the people,
Just as the people cannot exist without food.
The people’s hunger comes from their rulers’ excessive taxes—
Thus they hunger.
In the late periods of the Three Dynasties,
The great granaries were alike.
Once, the Five Hegemons contended for power,
Imposing labor and warfare,
Unequal rewards and burdens,
Scarce state resources,
Fields left uncultivated,
Taxes uncollected—
And yet they increased levies.
This is why the people starved.
When starving, they stole and schemed without restraint—
Thus they were difficult to govern.
Not that the people were difficult to govern,
But because their rulers acted.
When rulers act, the people act in turn.
The people’s indifference to death comes from their rulers’ excessive pursuit of life.
Those who exhaust a nation’s people
To nourish their ears, eyes, noses, and mouths—
Their spirits do not permit it.
Their spirits not permitted,
Thus they treat death lightly.
Only those who do not cling to life
Are wiser than those who prize it.
Why?
Because nourishing life must first be rooted in substance—
Yet even with abundance, many fail to nourish themselves.
If the laws of a declining age are followed,
Even the sages would not adopt them."*

The *Classic* says:
*"When a person is born, they are soft and weak;
When they die, they become stiff and strong.
All things, grass and trees—
When they are born, they are soft and fragile;
When they die, they wither and decay.
Thus, the stiff and strong are the companions of death,
The soft and weak are the companions of life—
Hence, strong armies do not conquer,
Strong trees are easily split.
The strong and great are beneath,
The soft and weak are above."*

The *Original Meaning* says:
*"Death and life are profound.
The companions of life, the companions of death—
I have already spoken of their essence in *Entering and Exiting Death*.
Alas, when a person is born, they are soft and weak—
The soft and weak are the companions of life.
When they die, they become stiff and strong—
The stiff and strong are the companions of death.
Is it only for humans?
All things are the same.
Thus it is also said:
All things, grass and trees—
When they are born, they are soft and fragile;
When they die, they wither and decay.
Trace their origin in life and death—
It lies in the two *qi* of yin and yang.
The two *qi* originate from the One *Qi* of the Supreme Polarity,
The One *Qi* originates from the Boundless Void of the Great Emptiness.
The *Classic* says:
*The myriad things under Heaven are born from Being,
Being is born from Non-Being.*
In the *Yijing*, it says:
*The Great Polarity is born from the *Yi*,
From which the Two Complements arise.*
The *Yi* is without yet reaches the utmost of Being—
To know the *Yi* is without yet reaches the utmost of Being,
Is to know the *Yi* is Boundless.
The *Yi* has the Great Polarity—
How could it not be called Boundless and the Great Polarity?
The Great Polarity is the undifferentiated *qi* at the origin of things,
The Boundless is the formless Great Emptiness before the Great Polarity.
The Buddhist school says:
*All dharmas return to One,
One returns to where?*
It is also the saying:
Being is born from Non-Being,
And again returns to Non-Being."*

Thus, what is the role of those who follow life, and what of those who follow death? From the Great Polarity arise the Two Complements—*Qian* the firm, *Kun* the yielding—heaven and earth uniting in virtue.

*Qian* is heaven. Heaven’s One generates water: the father is firm, the child yielding, so water’s nature is soft and weak, its virtue to follow downward. Earth’s Two generates fire: the mother is yielding, the child firm, so fire’s nature is flaming upward, its virtue dry and hard.

Were it not for fire’s firmness, *Qian*’s vigorous body would not manifest. Were it not for water’s yielding, *Kun*’s accommodating function would not be fulfilled. Only through the interplay of firm and yielding does the enduring and vast virtue emerge.

In birth, the human is soft and weak—heaven’s water sustains it. In death, it becomes rigid and strong—earth’s fire reclaims it. Only when firm and yielding balance does the work of life and death complete itself, and thus the Dao of longevity and enduring vision lies within. Hence, the nurturers of life take this as their law.

The yielding and weak give life; the firm and strong bring death. Just as a strong army cannot prevail—it is attacked by many—so too a rigid tree is felled by many axes. The firm and great are lowly; the yielding and weak are exalted. This is the Way of Heaven.

The sages and the old masters say: yielding and weak preserve *qi*; firm and strong deplete the body. When *qi* is harmonious, life flourishes; when the body is robust, aging comes. Aging leads to death, and death must return to its source. To return to the infant state, to return to the Boundless—this is the Way of return.

The *Classic* says: The Way of Heaven is like drawing a bow. The high are lowered; the low are raised. The excessive are diminished; the deficient are supplemented. Heaven’s Way is to diminish the excessive and supplement the deficient. But the Way of humanity is otherwise: it diminishes the deficient to serve the excessive. Who can serve the world with its excess? Only the Daoist.

Thus the sage acts without relying on it, achieves without claiming it, and does not seek to be seen as virtuous.

*The Original Meaning* says: In the *Hongfan*, the ninth category is *Huangji* (the Sovereign Polarity). The Sovereign establishes the Polarity, speaking of the central Way standing firm, its central path encompassing the nine categories.

The Way of Heaven is like drawing a bow. Using the analogy of drawing and releasing, the high are lowered, the low are raised—this is seen in the balance of high and low. The excessive are diminished, the deficient are supplemented—this is seen in the balance of great and small.

Earth’s *qi* ascends; heaven’s *qi* descends—this is the Way of lowering the high and raising the low. Extreme heat turns to cold; extreme cold turns to warmth—this is the Way of diminishing the excessive and supplementing the deficient. The Way of Heaven thus bends toward the middle, achieving harmony and establishing the positions of heaven and earth, nurturing all things.

But the Way of nurturing humanity is otherwise: it diminishes the deficient to serve the excessive. Heaven’s nature and human desires are ever in opposition. The so-called gentleman practices the Mean; the petty man rejects it. Who can serve the world with its excess, as heaven’s clouds move and rain nourishes all things? Only the Daoist—this is the saying: *Virtue lies in good governance; governance lies in nurturing the people.*

The sage acts without presumption, expecting no reward. When the work is done, he does not dwell on it—this is the Way of Heaven. He does not seek to be seen as virtuous; he simply holds to the Mean.

The sage’s deeds are both action and non-action, encompassing heaven and earth. The common people do not recognize this.

Ah! The heavens’ burden is without sound or scent.

The *Classic* says: Under Heaven, nothing is softer and weaker than water. Yet nothing surpasses it in overcoming the firm and strong. There is no substitute for it. Thus, the yielding overcomes the firm; the weak overcomes the strong. All know this, yet none can practice it.

Hence the sage says: To bear the nation’s impurities is to be its sovereign. To bear the nation’s misfortunes is to be its king. His words seem inverted.

*The Original Meaning* says: Softness overcomes hardness; the female overcomes the male—this is the principle. No thing is softer and weaker than water, yet when it reaches its fullness, it breaches dams and floods rivers, and none can resist it.

The old sages pitied the decline of the Xia and Shang dynasties, fearing the rise of a second age of decline. Thus, through the question of Guan Yin, they admonished and rescued them, saying: All know this, yet none can practice it. Only Lord Yu attained it, using water to control water, leveling the earth so heaven’s order was fulfilled. King Tang attained it, conquering east and west, ever fearful of falling behind. The Western King attained it, subduing the barbarians and punishing the arrogant, yet none dared to rebel.

Is this not the very essence of how the soft overcomes the hard? Had Jie understood this, he might have governed like the sage-kings Yu and Tang, and never would Tang have conquered him. Had Zhou understood this, he might have learned from the fall of Xia, and never would Wu have overthrown him. But because of their rigid cruelty and stubborn ignorance, there arose ministers who usurped their thrones—how dire the consequence!

Thus the sages declared: To bear a nation’s calamities is to be its sovereign. To bear a nation’s misfortunes is to be its king over all. These are the words of the ancient sages. When Gun was drowned, when Tang and Wen were imprisoned, none suffered greater calamities than they. Yet when Yu received the Mandate of Heaven through abdication, when Tang and Wu seized power themselves, they became sovereigns and kings over all.

Alas! Jie and Zhou were indeed tyrants as rulers, while Tang and Wu were indeed sages as subjects. If Yu, through merit, received the Mandate peacefully, then no reproach attaches. But if Tang and Wu, through cunning and force, took the throne themselves, how could they avoid shame? Only King Wen, with his utmost reverence toward Zhou, never straying from propriety, could be compared in virtue to Yao and Shun.

The true intent of *The Mysterious Classic* is to admonish rulers: Rectify yourself, and you rectify the people. Rectify the people, and the realm’s order is fulfilled. How could a subject ever presume to replace his sovereign?

The proper relationship between ruler and subject: I, the people of the Yellow Emperor’s age, were unshackled by laws yet content with our food—coarse grains to eat, hollowed gourds to drink from, simple garments to wear, fur to ward off cold, and shelters of nests and caves to shield us from wind and rain. We took joy in our customs, cradling our infants and patting our bellies in contentment. Neighboring lands lay in sight, yet our paths never clashed. The sounds of roosters and dogs reached one another, yet all things flourished without harm. The people lived to old age without seeking one another’s company, knowing no desire to contest cities or lands. Heaven’s Way and Earth’s bounty were never wanting.

To ponder this passage: the ancient simplicity and purity still resonates through heaven and earth—just as it was then, so it remains now. Thus we know the sages’ wisdom was beyond the grasp of later-age tyrants.

What they called a "great sage encountered once in ten thousand years" is one whose understanding dawns as naturally as day follows night.

*The Classic* says:
*"Faithful words lack beauty; beautiful words lack truth.
The virtuous do not argue; those who argue lack virtue.
The wise are not learned; the learned are not wise.
The sage does not hoard.
The more one gives to others, the more one possesses.
The more one shares with others, the more one has.
Heaven’s Way benefits without harming.
The sage’s Way acts without contention."*

*The Original Meaning* says:
The sage’s heart is the heart of heaven and earth—boundless in acceptance, boundless in giving. Like water poured in but never full, drawn upon but never exhausted.

But common people are otherwise:
Beautiful words lack truth, for they prize ornamentation.
Faithful words lack beauty, for the Way values simplicity.
The virtuous do not argue, for they embrace all without reservation.
Those who argue lack virtue, for they cling to words.
The wise are not learned, for they merge into oneness.
The learned are not wise, for they count without measure.
The sage does not hoard, for they align with the ebb and flow of time.
The more one gives to others, the more one possesses—
for the heart of nurturing life is ever-present.
The more one shares with others, the more one has—
for the heart of creation is inexhaustible.
Heaven’s Way benefits without harming.
Heaven’s lack of favor is itself the greatest favor.
The original intent of *The Mysterious Classic on Dao and Virtue* concludes here.

chunks.original_text: 道德玄经原旨 经名：道德玄经原旨。 亦称道德经原旨、老子原旨、玄经原旨。 元杜道坚撰。 四卷。 前有黎立武、账与材、牟巘、徐天佑等人序官。 底本出处：《正统道藏》 洞神部玉诀类。 道德玄经原旨序 《老》《易》无二道。 《易》有太极，圣经存而勿论，《易》首乾坤，后天之道也。 效天法地，故儒道与天地同功。 太易者，未见气，道家以为大道之祖，无名天地之始，先天之道也。 道法自然，故老圣得归无之妙。 噫，《道德》一经尽之矣。 余惟至道不烦，故尝寓诸图赞而不敢尽。 一日，内侄简成性至自杭见，谓比识南谷杜先生，其论多与图赞合，因得所着原旨，视余每叹世未有与论此事者，一读莫逆于心。 其曰玄之似无，而有又玄，似有而无，生物之天。 由此大着，自然之天，隐然长存。 曰太极中虚，谷神在焉。 谷虚善应者心，神静故灵者性。 曰太极乃物初浑沦之太一，无极乃太极未形之太虚。 曰道之为物十其一，则太极。 皆至论也。 闭门造车，出户合辙，信矣。 其有人乃若此经，上下古今之故顿见，五千言问，则又为之推阐明备，益信其非空言。 老君道迩太初之先，神游浩古之上，身历有周之末，天下之变，何所不阅，用垂训为千万世，则是何仁义之说。 世或病之，而未之思也。 大抵道德，以无极太极言，仁义礼智信，以阴阳五行言，所谓天地圣人刍狗民物，是为不仁，与六经育仁无异旨。 有如上德上仁，失道失德，绝仁绝智等论。 此则皇而帝，帝而王，道有升降，而伯氏假仁窃义僭礼凿於智者所为耳。 《原旨》实契乎斯义，且谓为民司命，不知有仁之生，礼之长，义之成，惟智藏是尚，是岁不春夏秋而常冬也，旨哉。 嗟乎，天道之流行，世道之推移，往而不返者，势也。 变而通之存乎人，斯经所以作。 其曰其精甚真，其中有信，五常之信，五行之土，先天无极，太极之道，万变不能易，所谓诚也。 成性行因摭经之要旨，书卷末归之。 大德乙巳上元西谷道人黎立武书。 《道德》八十一章，注者三千余家。 南谷着《原旨》，首曰《玄经》之旨，本为君上告。 又曰老圣作《玄经》，所以明皇道帝德也。 大纲大领，开卷甚明。 是经之在人间世，舒之弥六合，卷之入微尘，中固不可局一方。 《原旨》能识其大者，则小者不能违也。 吾闻南谷尝陪洞明入对，怀其耿耿者，而未及吐是书之作，殆其素蕴不得陈於当年，遂欲托之后世，得之者当不止汉文之治也。 南谷亦奇矣哉。 大德乙巳小雪嗣天师张与材序。 偪仄尘坱中，胸次愦愦，对俗人谭益不乐。 南谷杜君扁舟过余，论议超然，有以开余意，相与登道场云峰宿焉。 夜参半，篝灯，出所为《老子原旨》示余，不寐几彻晓。 杜君博极群书，不但发明其宗旨而已，於某章曰：是尧、舜之事也。 某章又曰：是禹、文王、武王之事也。 其说以为老聪为柱下史，所职者史，而百篇之书亦史也，故以书求之，余惊异焉。 自司马子长以老韩同传，千载不满。 河上公注《老子》，颇及吐纳导引之类。 其后孙登、陶弘景、松灵仙人、唐道士成玄英、张君相辈，亦皆注《老子》。 又近神仙家王辅嗣以《老子》解《易》，人或非之，然其解《老子》，则初不及《易》。
chunks.translated_text:
**The Original Purport of the Mysterious Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue**

**Title:** *The Original Purport of the Mysterious Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue* (also known as *The Original Purport of the Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue*, *The Original Purport of Laozi*, or *The Original Purport of the Mysterious Classic*). Composed by Du Daojian of the Yuan dynasty. Four juan. Prefaces by Li Liwu, Zhang Yucai, Mou Yan, Xu Tianyu, and others.

**Source Text:** *Zhengtong Daoist Canon*, *Dongshen* section, *Jade Instructions* category.

---

### **Preface to *The Original Purport of the Mysterious Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue***

The *Laozi* and the *Yijing* share the same Dao. The *Yijing* speaks of the Supreme Ultimate, yet the sacred scripture leaves it unelaborated. Its opening with *Qian* and *Kun* pertains to the Dao of the Posterior Heaven—modeled after heaven and earth, thus aligning the Confucian and Daoist paths with the workings of heaven and earth. The Supreme Change (*Taiyi*), unseen even in qi, is regarded by Daoists as the ancestor of the Great Dao, the nameless origin of heaven and earth, the Dao of the Prior Heaven. The Dao follows spontaneity, and thus the sage of old attained the wondrous return to nothingness. Alas! The entire *Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue* is contained herein.

I have long held that the supreme Dao is not cumbersome, and so I once expressed it through diagrams and eulogies without daring to exhaust its meaning. One day, my nephew Jiancheng Xing arrived from Hangzhou and told me that he had recently met Master Du of Nangu. Their discussions often aligned with my diagrams and eulogies, and so he obtained Master Du’s work, *The Original Purport*. Upon reading it, I sighed that no one in this world had ever discussed these matters with such resonance—every word struck a chord within. It speaks of the mysterious as seemingly nonexistent, yet existence itself is again mysterious, seemingly existent yet nonexistent, the heaven that gives birth to all things. From this great revelation, the heaven of spontaneity endures, hidden yet ever-present.

It states: "Within the emptiness of the Supreme Ultimate dwells the Valley Spirit." The valley’s emptiness, responsive and good, is the heart; the spirit’s stillness, numinous and true, is nature. It declares: "The Supreme Ultimate is the primordial undifferentiated Great One; the Limitless is the formless Great Void before the Supreme Ultimate." It further says: "Of the ten aspects of the Dao as a thing, the Supreme Ultimate is one." All these are profound discourses. As the saying goes, "Build a cart behind closed doors, and it will match the tracks when taken out"—truly so!

If one encounters a work like this, the causes and effects of past and present become instantly clear. Within the five thousand words of the *Laozi*, its principles are thoroughly expounded and elucidated, confirming that this is no empty rhetoric. Lord Lao’s Dao extends beyond the earliest beginnings; his spirit roams the boundless ancient past. He lived through the late Zhou dynasty, witnessing all the changes under heaven. To leave teachings for ten thousand generations—what benevolence and righteousness could surpass this? Yet some criticize it without reflection.

Generally, the Dao and its virtue are spoken of in terms of the Limitless and the Supreme Ultimate, while benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust are expressed through yin-yang and the Five Phases. The sage’s treatment of heaven, earth, and the myriad things as straw dogs is deemed "without benevolence," yet this aligns with the Six Classics’ nurturing of benevolence. Consider the discussions on "supreme virtue and supreme benevolence," "losing the Dao and losing virtue," "rejecting benevolence and abandoning wisdom"—these describe the progression from the August to the Emperor, from the Emperor to the King. The Dao rises and falls, while the hegemons usurp benevolence, steal righteousness, and falsify propriety through cunning. *The Original Purport* truly grasps this meaning.

Moreover, it states that the Dao governs the fate of the people, unaware of the life-giving power of benevolence, the growth fostered by propriety, the completion brought by righteousness—only the concealment of wisdom is esteemed. This is like a year without spring, summer, or autumn, perpetually in winter. How profound!

Alas! The flow of the heavenly Dao and the shifts of the worldly Dao, once gone, do not return—such is the inevitable trend. To adapt and preserve them lies with humanity, and thus this classic was composed. It says: "Its essence is most true; within it lies sincerity." The sincerity of the Five Constants is the earth of the Five Phases; the Dao of the Prior Heaven’s Limitless and the Supreme Ultimate cannot be altered by ten thousand changes—this is what is called *cheng* (integrity). Having gathered the essential purport of the classic to cultivate nature and conduct, I append it at the end of the scroll.

Written by Li Liwu of Xigu, on the Shangyuan Festival of the *yisi* year of the Dade era.

---

### **Preface by Zhang Yucai**

The eighty-one chapters of the *Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue* have been annotated by over three thousand scholars. Master Du of Nangu’s *Original Purport* begins with "The Purport of the Mysterious Classic," primarily addressed to rulers. It further states that the sage Lao composed the *Mysterious Classic* to elucidate the august Dao and the imperial virtue. Its grand principles and essential themes are made clear from the very first scroll.

In this world, the classic, when unfolded, fills the six directions; when rolled up, it enters the tiniest speck of dust. Its essence cannot be confined to one corner. *The Original Purport* grasps its greatness, and thus its lesser aspects cannot contradict it.

I have heard that Master Du of Nangu once accompanied Dongming in an imperial audience. Though he harbored earnest intentions, he did not have the chance to present this work. Perhaps his lifelong aspirations could not be expressed in his time, so he entrusted them to later generations. Those who obtain this work will achieve governance surpassing even that of Emperor Wen of Han. Master Du is truly extraordinary!

Written by Zhang Yucai, Inheritor of the Heavenly Master, on the Minor Snow of the *yisi* year of the Dade era.

---

### **Preface by Mou Yan**

In the cramped and dusty world, my heart is often troubled, and conversing with ordinary people brings no joy. When Master Du of Nangu arrived by boat, our discussions were transcendent, lifting my spirits. Together, we ascended the Cloud Peak of the Daoist sanctuary and lodged there. At midnight, by the light of a flickering lamp, he showed me his *Original Purport of Laozi*. I read through the night until dawn.

Master Du has studied extensively across all texts, and his work does more than merely elucidate the classic’s essential purport. On one chapter, he remarked, "This pertains to the affairs of Yao and Shun." On another, he said, "This concerns the deeds of Yu, King Wen, and King Wu." His interpretation treats Laozi as the Archivist of the Zhou, whose duty was to record history—and the hundred-chapter book is also history. Thus, he approached it through historical inquiry, which astonished me.

Ever since Sima Qian placed Laozi and Han Fei in the same biography, dissatisfaction has lingered for a thousand years. He Shanggong’s commentary on the *Laozi* frequently touches on breathing exercises and guiding-and-pulling techniques. Later, scholars like Sun Deng, Tao Hongjing, the Immortal of Pine Spirit, the Tang Daoist Cheng Xuanying, and Zhang Junxiang also annotated the *Laozi*. More recently, the immortalist Wang Fusi used the *Laozi* to interpret the *Yijing*, which some criticized. Yet his interpretation of the *Laozi* itself made no reference to the *Yijing*.

chunks.original_text: 至苏子由，直以是谓袭明，为释氏之传灯，《老子》亦岂意其末流之至此也。 今杜君乃求之以帝王之书，参之以帝王之事，譬如披蒙昧，出幽深，明向正大，气象顿殊，岂不甚题，或者曰此盖为原道解也。 呜呼，世未有能察杜君之用心者。 夫道术久裂，人各私其私，竞立门户，甚至保残护缺，以相非诋，莫肯旷能舍己求为真是之归。 杜君虽自号《原旨》，而不主一家，惟理是同，惟经是从，惟正是宗，务使天下后世无所置疑於其师之说，其用心盖若此，可谓弘也矣。 岂固与原道异哉。 余固陋於《原旨》未深究，姑论其大意云尔。 甲午谷雨陵阳牟巘书。 为老氏学者，率右老而左儒，列、庄二子，务尊其师，至诋訾尧、舜、孔子，用以相形。 故儒者指为异教，孔、老之学遂岐而二，然老教非果与儒戾也。 彼其为道，超有以用，无集虚以化实，直欲易圣智仁义，以素朴世。 儒往往骇於绝弃之言，夫岂知其矫也，而非真欤。 故善用其意，则西汉以清静治。 不善循其边，则西晋以清虚亡。 岂必弛纵绳墨，异吾所谓道哉。 南谷杜君之为是学也，不以道家说训老氏书，独援儒以明之。 章研句析，而前后相蒙，不喜为破碎，引类比义，悉举五三帝王、孔孟之道，传诸其说，如五色随物赋采，而调适以为绚也。 如五音清浊高下之相谐，而绎如成乐也。 如三十辐一毂殊涂束西行，而卒合辙也。 吾见其若一而已。 夫老教欲复结绳之治，则羲、农邃古之事也。 其谷神之论祖黄帝，其尚无为类舜，贵不伐不矜类禹。 诸微言眇旨，与六经合者，不可一二举。 观於众甫之会，谓孔、老不为一家，吾不信也。 杜君以上士闻道，由徽而妙，合异而同，太史公所谓道家精神专一，采儒之善者，非邪。 始余弱冠官昊兴，尝泛奉溪，今老矣。 一日，君往记介余友，示以所为《原旨》之书。 余虽不尽究其义，窃叹君之贯穿融液可谓勤且博矣。 览者当自详之。 粤遗民徐天佑斯万父书于一初山房。 余爱太史公记西都孝文时，人民乐业，年六七十翁，嬉戏如小儿。 太平盛际，犹可想见。 岂非学黄老师清净致然哉。 汉固不足征也。 老氏之书，大要言无为不争。 此隆古帝王之事，虽汤、武犹难之。 当周之衰，紫气度关而西也。 感慨时变，述五千言，而后行其辞，隐其旨，深其望於当世也。 厚书既传，非无宗尚。 其学者刑名深刻之术，神仙玄远之说，不能相发，而返以相病，况注者以百数，又不皆究其着经之本意。 南谷杜君《原旨》最后出，乃断之曰：是吾师探古史而作，以述羲、轩、尧、舜之道者也。 盖老氏职藏室史，旧闻未远，垂衣结绳之治，集然在目。 文莫信於史，以古史征之，而使人易信，实自今杜君始。 班固论道家清虚自守，合於尧之让，视君略焉。 抑固之志，九流析儒与道，道原於天圣，圣之所授受，夫不知其名，字之曰道，而专以是名家，果老氏意耶。 向今用其说，粹然壹返乎。 古孔氏之道，亦将有助矣。 君出儒家，从老氏学，能不私所主，而折衷二者之间，贤哉。 余虽愚昧，未究厥旨，异时计筹山中，分白云半席地，质疑辨惑，当有得於言语文字之外者。 山阴王易简理得父书。 道德玄经原旨卷之一 教门高士当涂杜道坚注
chunks.translated_text:
To Su Ziyou, who directly regarded it as an inheritance of enlightenment, a transmission of the lamp of the Śākya clan—how could the *Laozi* have foreseen that its later currents would reach such a state? Now, Master Du seeks it through the books of emperors and kings, cross-referencing it with their deeds. It is as if one emerges from darkness into light, from obscurity into grandeur, where the atmosphere and vision suddenly transform—how could this not be most fitting? Some say this is merely his *Origins of the Dao* commentary.

Alas, the world has yet to discern Master Du’s true intent. For long has the Way been fragmented, each clinging to their own biases, vying to establish sects, even preserving remnants and guarding gaps to disparage others. None are willing to set aside their prejudices and seek the convergence of truth. Though Master Du titles his work *Original Purport*, he does not adhere to a single school. He harmonizes only with principle, follows only the classics, and venerates only what is correct, striving to leave no room for doubt in later generations regarding his master’s teachings. Such is his intent—truly magnanimous. How could it fundamentally differ from the *Origins of the Dao*?

I, being of limited understanding, have not deeply examined the *Original Purport*, but I shall briefly discuss its general meaning.

Scholars of the Laozi’s teachings invariably favor Laozi over Confucius. The followers of Liezi and Zhuangzi go so far as to exalt their masters by disparaging Yao, Shun, and Confucius, using them as foils. Thus, Confucians label them as heterodox, and the teachings of Confucius and Laozi diverge into two paths. Yet the Laozi’s teachings were not inherently at odds with Confucianism. Its Way transcends being to function in non-being, gathering emptiness to transform the substantial, directly aiming to replace sagely wisdom and benevolence with a world of plain simplicity. Confucians often recoil at its radical renunciations, but how could they know whether such words are feigned or genuine?

When its principles are applied well, the Western Han governed through tranquility. When followed poorly to the extreme, the Western Jin perished through vacuity. Must one abandon all restraints and standards to claim it differs from what I call the Way?

Master Du of Nangu, in his study of this teaching, does not interpret the Laozi’s text through Daoist doctrines. Instead, he draws from Confucianism to illuminate it. Through meticulous analysis of chapters and phrases, he ensures coherence without fragmentation, preferring not to dissect it piecemeal. By drawing analogies and comparing meanings, he fully incorporates the Way of the Five Emperors, the Three Kings, and the teachings of Confucius and Mencius into his explanations. It is like the five colors adapting to their subjects, blending harmoniously into brilliance; like the five notes, high and low, clear and deep, resonating to form a perfect melody; like thirty spokes converging at a single hub, each taking different paths east and west, yet ultimately aligning in their tracks. In my view, his work achieves unity.

The Laozi’s teachings aspire to restore the governance of knotted cords—a practice of Fuxi and Shen Nong from the distant past. Its discourse on the Valley Spirit traces back to the Yellow Emperor; its esteem for non-action resembles Shun; its valuing of humility and lack of boasting mirrors Yu. Countless subtle words and profound meanings align with the Six Classics. Observing the convergence of all schools, to claim Confucius and Laozi do not belong to the same tradition—I do not believe it.

Master Du, as one who has heard the Dao and progressed from subtlety to wonder, harmonizing differences into unity, embodies what Sima Qian called the Daoist spirit: single-minded, yet incorporating the strengths of Confucianism. Is this not so?

In my youth, when I first took office in Wuxing, I once drifted along Fengxi. Now, in old age, one day Master Du sent a letter through a mutual friend, presenting me with his *Original Purport*. Though I have not fully grasped its meaning, I privately admire his exhaustive and erudite synthesis.

Readers should examine it in detail for themselves.

Written by the remnant subject Xu Tianyu, courtesy name Siwanfu, at Yichu Mountain Studio.

I recall Sima Qian’s record of the Western Capital during the reign of Emperor Wen of Han, when the people lived in joy, and elders of sixty or seventy played like children. The prosperity of that golden age can still be imagined. Was this not the result of studying the Yellow Emperor and Laozi’s teachings of tranquility? Yet the Han is not our only evidence.

The essence of the Laozi’s text lies in non-action and non-contention. These were the practices of the ancient sage-kings, which even Tang and Wu found difficult to uphold. As the Zhou declined, a purple aura crossed the pass westward. Moved by the times, Laozi composed his five thousand words, then departed, concealing his intent and deepening his hopes for the age. Once the text spread, it naturally found adherents. Yet its scholars—whether wielding the harsh techniques of Legalism or the abstruse theories of immortality—failed to mutually illuminate, instead turning to mutual criticism. Moreover, with hundreds of commentaries, few have truly grasped the original meaning of the classic.

Master Du of Nangu’s *Original Purport*, the last to emerge, decisively declares: This is my master’s exploration of ancient history, expounding the Way of Fuxi, the Yellow Emperor, Yao, and Shun. As Laozi served as the Archivist of the Zhou, the past was not distant, and the governance of "wearing robes and knotting cords" remained vividly before his eyes. No record is more trustworthy than history. To verify it through ancient history and make it easily credible—this truly begins with Master Du.

Ban Gu described Daoists as "vacuous and self-contained," aligning with Yao’s abdication, yet overlooking the ruler’s role. His *Treatise on the Nine Schools* separates Confucianism from Daoism, tracing the Dao’s origin to the Heavenly Sage. Yet the Sage’s transmission—nameless, designated only as the Dao—was later monopolized as a school. Was this truly Laozi’s intent? If his teachings were applied today, they would purely return to the ancient Way of Confucius, offering great assistance.

Master Du, hailing from the Confucian tradition yet studying the Laozi’s teachings, does not favor one over the other but reconciles both. How admirable! Though I am dull and have not fully grasped his intent, I hope one day to retreat to the mountains, sharing a patch of land beneath the white clouds, to resolve doubts and clarify uncertainties—perhaps gaining insight beyond mere words and texts.

Written by Wang Yijian, courtesy name Lidefu, of Shanyin.

*Original Purport of the Mysterious Classic of Dao and Virtue*, Volume One
Annotated by Du Daojian, Eminent Scholar of the Daoist Teachings of Dangtu

chunks.original_text: 《经》曰：道可道，非常道。 名可名，非常名。 无名，天地之始。 有名，万物之母。 常无，欲以观其妙。 常有，欲以观其徼。 此两者同出而异名，同谓之玄。 玄之又玄，众妙之门。 《原旨》曰：天群物之祖，道天之祖。 天不言道，何可言，可言非道欤。 曰不可道，不可名，自然之天，常而不变。 先天也。 可道，可名，生物之天，变而不常。 后天也。 于以见天 地始，万物母，征妙，有无，又玄众妙，包括大造化之元，殆无余矣。 观常无之妙，则见无名之始。 观无名之始，则见无极太极也。 观常有之缴，则见有名之母。 观有名之母，则见两仪万物也。 此两者本同乎始，出於母，而异其名。 两之又两之，则见玄之又玄，众妙之门也。 生物之天，由此大着。 自然之天，隐然长存。 形而上，形而下，天此道，吾此道，不言之言，无名之名，已不胜众奚假多言哉。 天不言，圣人亦欲无言，惜哉。 高言不止於众人之心，至言不出俗言胜也。 是以圣人不言，终不容於不言。 当时玄圣西游，关令尹喜，知其大道将隐，强为着书，不得已而言曰：道，可道，非常道。 名，可名，非常名。 关尹子曰：道，不可道，不可道，即道正。 为此道解也。 天地定位其间，二气复合为一，是谓冲和。 冲和具太极之体，为生化之根。 三才立而人道兴焉。 《书》曰：惟天地万物父母，惟人万物之灵。 自常无以上言天道，以下言人道，人能观天道而修人道，未有不入圣人之域者也。 《阴符经》曰：观天之道，执天之行，尽矣。 常无先天也，观妙则见固有之吾在。 常有后天也，观徼则见不亡之吾在。 原其始则无形而生有形，要其终则有形而归无形。 观诸日用常行事物之去来，吾心之动静，曾不外乎此道也。 此两者同出一道，而异其名。 同，同此道也。 玄一而二，二而一也。 玄之似无而有，又玄似有而无，众妙万物也。 门有出入之义，万物出於机而入於机，身具天地，心具太极，知而未尝生，未尝死也。 於戏，圣人之心，天地之心，观天地之朝霏暮霭，变化靡常，而太虚自若，则知圣人曰应万机，其心寂然，而天性自若也。 吾尝曰：天地大吾身，吾身小天地，若尧之荡荡乎。 民无能名焉者，可 谓有道圣人也已。 《经》曰：天下皆知美之为美，斯恶已。 皆知善之为善，斯不善已。 故有无之相生，难易之相成，长短之相形，高下之相倾，声音之相和，前后之相随。 是以圣人处无为之事，行不言之教。 万物作而不辞，生而不有，为而不恃，功成不居。 夫惟不居，是以不去。 《原旨》曰：道独立不偶，一有对待则物也。 物形物，美恶善否生焉。 若天地有大美而不言，尧有大善而不知，则亦何恶，何不善之有。 一有自矜自伐，欲人知己之心，则美反为恶，善斯不善矣。 况欲天下皆知乎。 古人有善，惟恐人知。 今人有善，恐人不知。 薄亦甚矣。 《玄经》之旨，本为君上告。 君上天下之师长也。 上有所好，下必从之。 《书》曰：惠迪吉从逆凶惟影响。 噫，非影动形，形动影也。 非谷动声，声动谷也。 可不慎诸。 故有无、难易、长短、高下、声音、前后，斯六者相生相成，相形相倾，相和相随，皆有对待，理所必然。 是以圣人事处无为，教行不
