chunks.original_text: 果而勿矜，果而勿伐，果而勿骄，果而不得已，是果而勿强。 物壮则老，是谓不道，不道早已。 《原旨》甲：人主之有天下，以其有土地之故。 有土地，斯有社稷。 有社稷，斯有人民。 社稷人民，天下之神器也。 上章以之劝人主以道，此章以其余旨戒人臣以兵。 於戏，老圣之用心至矣。 乃至不志天下，此其所以为百世师也。 天道好生恶杀，亏盈益谦，贵慈柔不贵强粱，慈柔则生，强梁则死，理之所必至。 故君子不得已而为。 天下苍生一出铃以道，为人主佐，保社稷安人民，次不以兵强天下，为社稷倾人民毒也。 况兵无常胜，其事好还，败亦随之，可不戒乎。 使为人臣而不能佐主以道，肆行不恤，黩武食功，谋动干戈於邦内以土地，故糜烂其民以战，民不堪命，不死於兵，则避而去之。 兵强之祸，天下如此。 师之所处，耕耨既废，荆棘生焉。 兴师百里，百里之害。 兴师千里，千里之害。 大军既兴之后，不待水旱作而年已凶矣。 岂人臣之善道哉。 善者果而已，不敢以取强，则宜审所取合也。 观孔子以俎豆对灵公之问陈，则知兵不足言以去兵。 答子贡之问政，则知兵乃可去。 噫嘻，孔圣忧天下之心，又何异於老圣乎。 果而勿矜，勿伐，勿骄，果而不得已，言天理之所在，如吾之所说者，是皆知其必不得已，而须如此行，方是果而勿强之道也。 物壮则老，人臣位极，身不知退，尚以舞兵弄权为事，极则危矣。 是之谓不知道，不道早已，而况弓藏犬烹，只足以自速其颠脐也。 尚何望佐人主而政国治而天下平乎。 闻之者足以戒。 《经》曰：夫佳兵者不祥之器，物或恶之，故有道者不处。 ，君子居则贵左，用兵则贵右。 兵者不祥之器，非君子之器，不得已而用之。 恬淡为上，胜而不美。 而美之者，是乐杀人。 夫乐杀人者，不可得志於天下。 吉事尚左，凶事尚右，偏将军处左，上将军处右，言以丧礼处之。 杀人众多，以悲哀泣之。 战胜，以丧礼处之。 《原旨》曰：弧矢威天下，其来久矣。 然则天下盗弧矢以侮天子，古已不少，兵可不慎乎。 兵者，杀人之器。 而曰佳兵，必有乐杀人者矣。 不祥之器，凶器也。 前言神器，此言凶器，或以神，或以凶，则物或恶之，岂有有天下而可使物有恶之之心乎。 故有道者不处。 此承上章余旨，为人臣好用兵者戒也。 当天下无事之时，君子在位贵在于左，及其有事用兵之际，贵在右矣。 兵者，不祥之器，非君子之器，不得已而用之。 当必以恬淡为上。 恬淡云者王者之师，志在抚民，不事俘诚，而无诡谲之心，故虽胜而不以为美。 若以为美，是乐杀人。 夫乐杀人者，不可得志於天下。 如楚子玉之於城濮，晋先谷之於邲，皆主用兵而好战者，终不可以得志。 孟子告梁襄王曰：不嗜杀人者，能一之。 又曰：天下莫不与也，安有以杀人为乐，而能得志於天下者哉。 左尊位，右卑位，吉事尚左，为可喜也。 凶事尚右，为可哀也。 偏将军本卑以不专杀，故处左，居以尊位。 上将军本尊以司杀柄，故处右，居以卑位。 正谓凶不可尚也。 噫，当受命于将，将在军，君令有所不受。 於斯时也，君之心当何如哉，危矣。 故又以偏将军处左，防危之心可见也。 上将军处右，不祥之名可见也。
chunks.translated_text:
「Thus, the fruits of action must be reaped without arrogance,
without boasting,
without pride,
and only when unavoidable—
this is the way of reaping fruits without force.

When things reach their peak, they grow old—
this is called *not* the Dao.
Not the Dao means early ruin.

*The Original Meaning* states:
Chapter A: When rulers possess the world,
it is because they have the land.
With the land, there are ancestral altars.
With ancestral altars, there are the people.
The ancestral altars and the people—
these are the sacred tools of the world.
The previous chapter admonished rulers with the Dao,
this chapter warns ministers against using arms.
Ah! The wisdom of the ancient Sage is profound indeed.
Even to not aspire to the world—
this is why he stands as a teacher for a hundred generations.

The Dao of Heaven favors life and abhors killing,
filling the abundant and nourishing the modest,
valuing gentleness and not favoring harshness.
Gentleness brings life,
harshness brings death—
this is the inevitable course of nature.

Thus, the virtuous act only when unavoidable.
When the people of the world are led by the Dao,
the ministers should assist the ruler,
protect the ancestral altars,
and ensure the people’s safety.
If they instead use arms to dominate the world,
they overturn the ancestral altars,
poison the people—
this is even worse.
Moreover, arms have no constant victor,
their consequences return naturally,
and defeat follows swiftly—
how can one not be warned?

If ministers cannot assist their ruler with the Dao,
but instead indulge in reckless warfare,
boast of martial prowess,
and scheme for glory within the state,
then they waste their people through battle.
The people cannot endure,
and if they do not die in war,
they flee and abandon the land.
The calamities of arms are such across the world.
Where the army marches,
plowing and weeding cease,
and thorns and brambles grow.
A hundred *li* of war brings harm to a hundred *li*.
A thousand *li* of war brings harm to a thousand *li*.
After great armies are raised,
without waiting for floods or droughts,
the years become calamitous.
Is this the Dao of a virtuous minister?

The virtuous achieve only what is fitting,
daring not to take by force—
thus, they should carefully examine what they take.

Observe Confucius, when answering Duke Ling’s inquiry about warfare at a sacrificial feast,
and you will know that arms are not to be spoken of lightly.
When answering Zigong’s question about governance,
you will know that arms can be abandoned.
Alas! The Sage Confucius’ concern for the world—
how is it different from the ancient Sage’s?

To reap fruits without arrogance,
without boasting,
without pride,
and only when unavoidable—
this means that when natural reason dictates,
as in what I have spoken,
one must know that it is unavoidable
and proceed accordingly—
only then does one embody the Dao of reaping without force.

When things reach their peak, they grow old—
if ministers, at the height of their power,
do not know when to retreat,
but instead engage in military posturing and political games,
then danger is near.
This is called *not* knowing the Dao,
and not the Dao means early ruin—
how much more so when bows are stored and dogs are slaughtered,
only hastening their own downfall!

How then can they hope to assist the ruler,
bring order to the state,
and achieve peace in the world?
Those who hear this should take heed.

*The Classic* states:
*"Fine arms are ominous instruments,
which things often detest,
so those who follow the Dao do not wield them.
The virtuous should honor the left in peace,
but honor the right in war.
Arms are ominous instruments,
not the tools of the virtuous,
used only when unavoidable.
Serenity and simplicity are supreme.
Victory should not be gloried in—
to glory in it is to delight in killing.
Those who delight in killing cannot aspire to rule the world.
Auspicious matters favor the left,
ominous matters favor the right.
The lesser general is placed on the left,
the supreme general on the right—
this is to liken them to funeral rites.
When many are killed,
they should be mourned with sorrowful tears.
Victory should be treated as funeral rites."*

*The Original Meaning* says:
*"Bows and arrows have long threatened the world,
and yet the world has always had those who steal them
to defy the Son of Heaven—
this has been so since ancient times.
How can arms not be treated with caution?
Arms are instruments of killing.
Yet they are called 'fine arms'—
there must be those who delight in killing.
Ominous instruments are instruments of harm.
Earlier, they were called sacred tools,
now they are called instruments of harm—
sometimes revered as sacred,
sometimes reviled as ominous—
how can one possess the world
while allowing such conflicting hearts to arise?
Thus, those who follow the Dao do not wield them.
This follows the remaining meaning of the previous chapter,
warning ministers who love to use arms.*

When the world is at peace,
the virtuous in office should value the left.
But when war arises,
they should value the right.
Arms are ominous instruments,
not the tools of the virtuous,
used only when unavoidable.
They should always uphold serenity and simplicity as supreme.

Serenity and simplicity—
the ruler’s teacher seeks to nurture the people,
not to revel in captives and deceit,
nor to harbor treacherous intentions.
Thus, though they may win,
they do not take pride in it.
If they do take pride,
it is because they delight in killing.
Those who delight in killing cannot aspire to rule the world.

Like the Duke of Chu’s Ziyou at Chengpu,
or Jin’s Xianguo at Ji,
all those who wield arms and love war
ultimately cannot achieve their ambitions.

Mencius told King Xiang of Liang:
*"Those who do not delight in killing can unite the world.
Again he said:
The world has no one who does not seek harmony,
how can one who delights in killing
aspire to rule the world?"*

The left is the honored position,
the right is the lowly position.
Auspicious matters favor the left—
this is joyful.
Ominous matters favor the right—
this is sorrowful.
The lesser general is placed on the left,
for he does not bear sole responsibility for killing,
and thus is given an honored position.
The supreme general is placed on the right,
for he holds the power of life and death,
and thus is given a lowly position.
This clearly shows that ominous matters should not be honored.

Alas! When receiving orders from the general,
the general commands the army,
and the ruler’s orders may not always be obeyed.
At such times, how should the ruler’s heart be?
It is perilous.
Thus, the lesser general is placed on the left,
to show the need for caution,
while the supreme general is placed on the right,
to bear the ominous name of war.»

chunks.translated_text:
The **Dao** is ever nameless.
The **uncarved block**—though small—
the world dare not enslave.
If lords and kings could guard it well,
all things would come as guests.

Heaven and Earth unite,
and sweet dew descends.
No command from Heaven,
yet all is balanced.
At first, the **Dao** was nameless,
but when names were given,
Heaven knew to halt.
To know when to stop
is how one avoids ruin.

Like the **Dao** in the world,
it is akin to streams and valleys
with the great rivers and seas.

The *Original Meaning* says:
The **Dao** is ever nameless—
nameless, hence honored.
The **uncarved block** has no form—
no form, hence vast.
Only by not dwelling in what is honored and vast
does it remain small yet unassailable by the world.
If lords and kings could embody
this nameless honor and formless greatness,
guard it without loss,
they would not need to proclaim their virtue to all under Heaven—
yet the multitude of people and things
would naturally submit.

For lords and kings to the people,
as Heaven and Earth to all things,
this response and that reaction
are governed by one principle.

Observe Heaven and Earth’s weaving and binding,
the union of yin and yang,
and sweet dew descends—
nothing but the **harmony of balance** at work.

That which is balanced without command
shows how all things first divided,
their **spirit-essence and vital qi** allotted,
their beginnings and growth
requiring not a hair’s breadth of human effort.

From the **Dao**’s nameless origin
to the giving of names,
each thing follows its own principle.
Once names are given,
when deeds are done and matters settled,
Heaven knows to halt—
the **Dao** of withdrawal.

The ancients who grasped this
were exalted as emperors or kings.
Those who do not know the **Dao**,
the **Way** is long past—
how much more so
when bows are stored and dogs are boiled,
only hastening their own downfall?

How then could they hope
to aid the sovereign’s rule,
govern the state in order,
and bring peace to the world?
Hearers of this should take warning.

The *Scripture* says:
**"Excellent weapons are not auspicious instruments**—
things may detest them,
so those who follow the **Dao** do not dwell upon them.
The gentleman in peace values the left,
in war values the right.

Weapons are not auspicious instruments,
not the tools of the gentleman,
used only when there is no other choice.
Calm and unassuming is the highest virtue,
to conquer yet not take pleasure in it.

But those who take pleasure in it
delight in killing people.
Those who delight in killing people
cannot hope to prevail in the world.

Auspicious matters favor the left—
this is joyful.
Ominous matters favor the right—
this is sorrowful.
The lesser general is placed on the left,
for he does not bear sole responsibility for killing,
and thus is given an honored position.
The supreme general is placed on the right,
for he holds the power of life and death,
and thus is given a lowly position.
This clearly shows that ominous matters should not be honored.

Alas! When receiving orders from the general,
the general commands the army,
and the ruler’s orders may not always be obeyed.
At such times, how should the ruler’s heart be?
It is perilous.
Thus, the lesser general is placed on the left,
to show the need for caution,
while the supreme general is placed on the right,
to bear the ominous name of war.

The *Scripture* says:
Weapons are treated with funeral rites—
the ominous nature is evident.
When many are slain,
it is mourned with sorrowful weeping.
When victory is won,
it is treated with funeral rites—
is this not something one should endure with reluctance?

If not an enemy state invading us,
yet unrest lingers below,
and one must use force,
it should not be raised lightly.

The ancient kings had a heart
that could not bear to harm others—
thus they governed with a policy
that could not bear to harm others.

The *Scripture* says:
The **Dao** is ever nameless.
The **uncarved block**—though small—
the world dare not enslave.
If lords and kings could guard it well,
all things would come as guests.

Heaven and Earth unite,
and sweet dew descends.
No command from Heaven,
yet all is balanced.
At first, the **Dao** was nameless,
but when names were given,
Heaven knew to halt.
To know when to stop
is how one avoids ruin."

chunks.original_text: 譬道之在天下，犹川谷之与江海。 《原旨》曰：道常无名，无名故尊。 朴本无形，无形故大。 惟尊大而不处尊大，故虽小，天下莫敢臣。 侯王若能体此无名之尊，无形之大，守而勿失，当不待诞告万方，而民物之众将自宾服矣。 盖王侯之於万民，天地之於万物，此感彼应，同乎一理。 观天地絪缢，阴阳相合，以降甘露，无非中和所致。 夫莫之令而自均，当知物初分灵布气，资始资生，曾不烦一毫人力之为也。 由道常无名而始制有名，一物一理，名亦既有，功成事遂，天亦将知止，身退之道也。 古之人有得之者，上为皇而下为王，伏羲、文王也。 伏羲得之而为皇，作先天六画，乾南坤北，天地定位，始制有名，皇道兴焉。 迨文王得之王，道大成名亦既有也。 而作后天八卦，乾退西北，坤退西南，天亦将知止矣。 知止所以不殆。 退得其时，又何危焉。 皇王之风，於焉可见。 圣人檃括天地，发明道朴，为侯王者，告曲譬妙，理可谓殆尽。 犹恐后世未喻其旨，故又取其近者而言之，曰譬道之在天下，犹川谷之与江海。 释见前知其雄将欲取天下章。 《经》曰：知人者知，自知者明。 胜人者有力，自胜者强。 知足者富，强行者有志。 不失其所者久，死而不亡者寿。 《原旨》曰：人死生亦大矣。 究其所以，明而为人，幽而为鬼神，明则复为人，无古今无智愚一也。 然则有生之曰，穷通得失，轮云翻覆，情随事迁，相与俯仰一世，如造物之晦明变化，舒惨靡常，一日万状，使无道以处之，宁无造次颠沛者哉。 故必先知己知彼，而后可以尽应世接物，为人之道，而知生知死者也。 知人者智，自知者明。 知之云者非知彼我之乡党亲戚也，非知彼我之功名事业也，知其心而已。 知人之心，则事无责备不其智乎。 知己之心，则事无苟越不其明乎。 胜人者有力，人欲炽也。 自胜者强，天理明也。 知足者富，内□实也，强行者有志，体刚健也。 不失其所者，久得其中庸也。 死而不亡者，寿全体而归也。 夫人之出处安常，修短随化，不惟有可久之德，可大之业，以寿斯世，彼明而为人，幽则为鬼神者，僭然若亡而存，油然不形而神，真有不亡者在。 《经》曰：大道泛兮，其可左右。 万物恃之以生而不辞，功成不名有。 爱养万物而不为主，常无欲，可名於小。 万物归之而不为主，可名於大。 是以圣人终不为大，故能成其大。 《原旨》曰：圣人爱养百姓，不以功名自大，体道故也。 天下载之而不重，乐推而不默，虽不欲大，不可也。 大道泛兮，无往不在，其可左右。 随其所之，万物恃之以生而不辞，物得以生，曾无辞谢。 功成不名有，成所当成，何功之有。 爱养万物而不为主，生所当生，爱养必至乌可为主，常无欲，可名於小。 谦德至矣。 万物归之而不为主，可名於大。 无归物之心，物自归之。 无大物之心，物自大之。 道之为道也。 若此是以圣人体道为心，爱养万民，虽有大功大德，终不自以为大，故天下归之，自能成其大也。 吾终此章，隐几默味，游心上古，乃见羲皇上人标枝野鹿，大朴淳风，熙熙犹在也。 《经》曰：执大象，天下往。 往而不害，安平泰。 乐与饵，过客止。 道之出口，淡乎其无味。 视之不足见，听之不足闻，用之不可既。
chunks.translated_text:
The **Dao** in the world is like rivers and valleys to the seas.

*The Original Meaning* says:
The **Dao** is ever nameless—
nameless, hence revered.
The **uncarved block** has no form—
no form, hence vast.
Though it does not dwell in reverence or vastness,
it is small yet none dare enslave it.
If lords and kings could embody this nameless reverence,
this formless vastness,
and guard it without loss,
they would not need to proclaim their virtue to all under heaven—
yet the multitude of people and things would submit as guests.

For lords and kings to the people,
as Heaven and Earth to all things,
this response and that reaction—
they share the same principle.
Observe how Heaven and Earth, in their interplay,
with yin and yang united,
descend sweet dew—
all arising from the **harmony of balance**.
None commands it, yet all is equal.
At first, the **Dao** was nameless,
but when names were given,
one thing, one principle—
names given, deeds accomplished,
Heaven knows when to halt—
the **Way of withdrawal**.

The ancients who grasped this
were **Emperors above** and **Kings below**—
Fuxi and King Wen.
Fuxi attained it as **Emperor**,
drawing the six primordial strokes,
with **Heaven** to the south and **Earth** to the north,
fixing their positions,
and first giving names—
thus the **Emperor’s Way** flourished.
When King Wen attained it as **King**,
the **Dao** was fully realized—
names had been given.
He then composed the eight trigrams of **Later Heaven**,
with **Heaven** withdrawing to the northwest,
**Earth** to the southwest—
Heaven knew when to halt.
To know when to halt
is how one avoids ruin.
Withdrawing at the right time—
what danger could there be?
The **Emperor-King’s** spirit is thus revealed.

The Sage gathers the essence of Heaven and Earth,
clarifying the **uncarved block**,
and for those who would be lords and kings,
explains it in parables and mysteries—
the principles are now fully laid out.
Yet fearing later ages might not grasp its meaning,
he speaks again in closer terms:
*"The **Dao** in the world is like rivers and valleys to the seas."*

This elucidates what was seen earlier:
*"The heroic, about to take the world."*

*The Scripture* says:
He who knows others is wise,
he who knows himself is enlightened.
He who overcomes others has strength,
he who overcomes himself is powerful.
He who knows contentment is rich,
he who perseveres has resolve.
He who does not lose his place endures,
he who dies yet does not perish is long-lived.

*The Original Meaning* says:
Life and death are great matters indeed.
Examined closely,
when one is manifest, they are human;
when hidden, they are spirits and gods.
Manifest, they return to humanity—
no ancient or modern, no wise or foolish—
all the same.
Yet in life,
prosperity and adversity, gain and loss,
cycle like clouds—
emotions shift with circumstances,
as one bows and rises through an age,
like the Creator’s alternating dark and bright,
expanding and contracting—
ever-changing, a myriad forms in a day.
Without the **Dao** to guide them,
who would not stumble and fall?

Thus one must first know self and others,
then can fully respond to the world and engage with things—
the **Way of humanity**,
the **Way of knowing life and death**.

He who knows others is wise,
he who knows himself is enlightened.
By "know," I do not mean knowing their clans or kin,
their achievements or deeds—
only their hearts.
To know another’s heart,
what task could not be accomplished with wisdom?
To know one’s own heart,
what action could not be measured with clarity?

He who overcomes others has strength—
for desire burns fiercely in them.
He who overcomes himself is powerful—
for Heaven’s principle is clear.
He who knows contentment is rich—
for his inner substance is full.
He who perseveres has resolve—
for his body is strong and healthy.
He who does not lose his place endures—
for he abides in the **Middle Way**.
He who dies yet does not perish is long-lived—
for his essence returns whole.

Mortals, in their rise and fall,
their lifespan fixed by transformation,
do not merely possess enduring virtue or great deeds
to prolong this age—
but those who are manifest as human,
hidden as spirits and gods,
seem to vanish yet endure,
unseen yet divine—
truly, the unperishing exists.

*The Scripture* says:
The **Great Dao** flows—
it can be neither grasped nor resisted.
All things rely on it to live,
yet it does not claim credit.
It accomplishes without naming itself.
It nurtures all things yet does not rule—
ever without desire,
it may be called **small**.
All things return to it yet it does not rule—
it may be called **great**.
Thus the Sage never claims greatness,
and so achieves true greatness.

*The Original Meaning* says:
The Sage nurtures the people,
not boasting of achievements or virtue—
for he embodies the **Dao**.
Though the world bears him up without burden,
and he delights in spreading virtue without restraint,
though he does not desire greatness,
it is inevitable.
The **Great Dao** flows—
omnipresent, neither left nor right.
Wherever it goes,
all things rely on it to live,
yet it does not refuse.
Things live because of it—
no refusal, no gratitude.
It accomplishes without claiming credit—
what deeds remain to claim?
It nurtures all things yet does not rule—
what it should nurture, it nurtures—
how could it claim mastery?
Ever without desire,
it may be called **small**—
the ultimate in humility.
All things return to it yet it does not rule—
it may be called **great**.
With no intention to receive,
things come of their own accord.
With no intention to be great,
things grow great of their own accord.
Such is the **Dao** in its essence.
Thus the Sage takes the **Dao** as his heart,
nurtures all the people,
though his deeds and virtues are great,
he never considers himself great—
and so the world submits,
and he achieves true greatness.

I conclude this chapter,
leaning back, savoring in silence,
wandering in spirit to antiquity,
and there I see the **Emperor of Primordial Times**,
his followers like wild deer,
the **Great Uncarved** in its pure simplicity—
still vibrant, as if alive.

*The Scripture* says:
Hold fast to the **Great Symbol**—
the world will come.
Come without harm,
secure and at peace.
Joy and bait—
passengers will stop.
When the **Dao** leaves the mouth,
it is bland, without taste.
To look at it, insufficient to see;
to listen, insufficient to hear;
to use it, inexhaustible.

chunks.original_text: 《原旨》曰：道大无外，圣人则而象之，以长天下。 四夷八蛮，兼爱并养，物无不均，故天下归往焉。 往而不害，来则安之，安则平，平则泰矣。 古之人有行之者，黄帝是也。 观天之道，执天之行，故能垂衣裳而天下治。 然则奚为治哉。 乐与饵，过客止。 干戈之於叛寇，犹乐饵之於过客。 客至则张乐饵以燕之，过则止也。 当蚩尤之乱必诛，干戈斯作。 炎帝之归必宥，兵斯可偃。 兵不可常乐，亦不可常以礼，饮酒者，始乎治，常卒乎乱。 泰至则多奇乐，凡事亦然。 始乎谅，常卒乎鄙。 其始也，叉简。 其毕也。 必巨。 兵其可不知戒乎。 道之为言，出乎口而淡乎其无味，非乐饵比也，如大象焉。 象无形，故视之不足见。 象无声，故听之不足闻。 圣人则而用之妙不可既。 《经》曰：将欲噏之，必固张之。 将欲弱之，必固强之。 将欲废之，必固兴之。 将欲夺之，必固与之，是谓微明。 柔弱胜刚强。 鱼不可脱於渊，国之利器，不可以示人。 《原旨》曰：昼夜明晦，人物盛衰，今古之不停者，以其有大造化，流行于宇宙之间。 物有不可得而逃之，如春将温，冬必寒，秋将凉，夏必热，迭运不易，自然之理也。 造化何心哉。 是故寒暑相推，而岁功成焉。 将欲噏之，必固张之，阖辟也。 将欲弱之，必固强之，损益也。 将欲废之，必固兴之，否泰也。 将欲夺之，必固与之，生杀也。 是之谓大造化之微而可明者。 然则柔弱胜刚强。 柔弱，气之为物也。 物变则通。 刚强，形之为物也。 物壮则老。 知变通而不堕壮老，则胜斯在我肯为甚乎。 鱼不可脱於渊。 鱼，民也。 渊，国也。 水，利器也。 利器，货食之谓。 渊有水则鱼安，国足货食则民安。 水藏于渊，则鱼不脱去。 货食藏于天下，则民不脱去。 为人君而长一国者，可以聚敛之端示乎人哉。 知大造化之流行，盈虚消息，理有常度，则会计之心，自有不必容者，况国之利用，遍藏天下，犹水之冬涸春盈，未尝不足，又何患焉。 《经》曰：道常无为，而无不为。 侯王若能守，万物将自化。 化而欲作，吾将镇之以无名之朴。 无名之朴，亦将不欲，不欲以静，天下将自正。 《原旨》曰：道常无为，而无不为。 道有当为有不当为之常理，不为其所不当为，而为所当为。 则春春而夏夏，阴阳不忒，不待言而四时行。 品物亨道一反常，则沴气乃作，四时乖和，品物伤矣。 君道亦然。 侯王若能体道之道，而守君之当为，不为君之所不当为，则君君而臣臣，厥分罔差。 君不言而百官正，万物将自化也。 社稷人民，莫不各安厥分，为所当为，不为其所不当为矣。 帝德一愆，异政乃起，使君而尽君道，臣而尽臣道，上不凌下，下不僭上，天下曷敢有越厥志而不从王化者哉。 化而欲作，是既化而又欲有他作之心也。 为君之道，当思彼胡为而欲作，必有启之者矣。 当勿待彼作而亟，求吾之所未当，反其所当，而镇之以静。 夫如是，则必使人之意也，消有不待，以彰厥罪，而彼将自化也。 何敢复作哉。 是之谓吾将镇之以无名之朴。 无名之朴，亦将不欲，上惭厥德，下畏厥威，又当忘言，恬若罔闻，是之谓亦将不欲也。 不欲则以此而自静，天下将自正矣。 道之无为而无不为也。 若此世之人，有必如块然木石，而后谓之无为者，则安得而无不为哉。
chunks.translated_text:
*The Original Essence* says:
The **Dao** is vast without bounds—
the Sage follows its pattern and embodies it,
to nurture all under Heaven.

The **Four Quarters** and **Eight Barbarians**,
all are embraced with love and nourished,
their needs met without measure—
thus the world comes to him.

When they come, they are unharmed,
settled in peace,
peace brings tranquility,
tranquility brings harmony.

The ancients who practiced this—
**Yellow Emperor** was one.
Observing the **Dao** of Heaven,
holding fast to its ways,
he ruled with ease while all under Heaven was ordered.

Yet what is this "order"?
Joy and bait—
passengers stop when they arrive.
Weapons against rebels
are like joy and bait for travelers:
when guests come, spread music and food to entertain them,
and they will stay—
then depart.

When **Chiyou**’s chaos arose, it must be punished—
weapons were raised.
When **Yandi** returned, he was pardoned—
weapons could then be laid down.

Weapons cannot always be wielded,
nor can they always be governed by ritual.
Drinking wine begins with order,
but ends in disorder.

When harmony reaches its peak,
strange delights arise—
so too with all things:
beginning with sincerity,
ending in vulgarity.
At first, it is simple,
but when complete,
it becomes excessive.
Thus, weapons—
how can one not be wary?

The **Dao** as speech,
when spoken, is bland without taste—
not like joy and bait,
but like the **Great Symbol**.

The **Symbol** has no form,
so it cannot be seen.
The **Symbol** has no sound,
so it cannot be heard.
The Sage follows and applies it—
its use is boundless.

*The Scripture* says:
To seek to nourish,
first stretch it taut.
To seek to weaken,
first strengthen it.
To seek to abandon,
first establish it.
To seek to take,
first give it—
this is called **subtle clarity**.

The soft overcomes the hard.
Fish cannot escape the deep—
a state’s sharp tools
should not be displayed to the people.

*The Original Essence* says:
Day and night alternate in brightness and obscurity,
people and things wax and wane—
the unceasing flow of antiquity and present,
for **Great Transformation** moves through the cosmos.
Some things cannot escape:
spring brings warmth, winter brings cold,
autumn brings coolness, summer brings heat—
their cycles shift without end,
the natural order.

What intent does **Transformation** have?
Thus cold and heat succeed each other,
and the year’s work is complete.
To seek to nourish,
first stretch it taut—
this is **opening and closing**.
To seek to weaken,
first strengthen it—
this is **subtraction and addition**.
To seek to abandon,
first establish it—
this is **negation and affirmation**.
To seek to take,
first give it—
this is **life and death**.
This is the **subtle yet clear** work of **Great Transformation**.

Thus the soft overcomes the hard.
Softness is the nature of **qi**.
Things change and flow.
Hardness is the nature of form.
Things grow strong and then decay.
To know change and flow,
without falling into rigidity or decay—
then victory lies within our grasp.

Fish cannot escape the deep.
Fish are the people,
the deep is the state,
water is the sharp tools.
Sharp tools are wealth and food.
When the deep holds water, fish are secure;
when the state has wealth and food, the people are secure.
Water hidden in the deep—
fish do not flee.
Wealth and food hidden in the world—
the people do not flee.

For a ruler governing a state,
can he display the means of accumulation to the people?
Knowing the flow of **Great Transformation**,
the ebb and flow of fullness and emptiness,
the fixed principles of nature—
then the mind of reckoning
will naturally have no need for excess.
How much more so when the state’s resources
are stored throughout the world,
like water drying in winter and filling in spring—
never lacking—
what need for worry?

*The Scripture* says:
The **Dao** acts without action,
yet nothing remains undone.
If lords and kings could uphold it,
all things would transform of their own accord.
If transformation begins to stir,
I will steady it with the **Unnamed Primordial**.

The **Unnamed Primordial** will also not desire—
not desiring, it remains still,
and the world will align itself.

*The Original Essence* says:
The **Dao** acts without action,
yet nothing remains undone.
The **Dao** has fixed principles:
what should be done and what should not.
Not doing what should not be done,
doing what should be done—
then spring will be spring,
summer will be summer,
yin and yang will not err,
without words, the four seasons proceed.
If things and their **Dao** reverse their nature,
disastrous **qi** arises,
the seasons lose harmony,
and things are harmed.

So too with governance.
If lords and kings embody the **Dao** of governance,
upholding what the ruler should do,
not doing what the ruler should not—
then rulers will be rulers,
ministers will be ministers,
their roles without error.
The ruler need not speak,
and all officials will be correct.
All things will transform of their own accord.

The altars and people—
none will dare overstep their place,
doing what they should,
not doing what they should not.

If imperial virtue falters,
alternative policies arise.
If the ruler fully embodies the **Dao** of rule,
and ministers fully embody the **Dao** of service,
superiors do not oppress inferiors,
inferiors do not overstep superiors—
how could anyone dare defy their will
and not conform to the **Dao**?

If transformation begins to stir,
it means that after transformation,
there is still another desire to act.
The ruler’s path must consider:
*Why does this desire to act arise?*
There must be those who provoke it.
Do not wait for them to act first—
examine what I have not yet done correctly,
return to what is correct,
and steady it with stillness.

Thus, their intentions will naturally dissipate,
their crimes exposed without need for words,
and they will transform of their own accord.
How dare they act again?

This is called:
*I will steady it with the **Unnamed Primordial**.*
The **Unnamed Primordial** will also not desire—
the ruler, ashamed of his virtue,
the people, fearful of his might—
he must also forget speech,
serene as if unaware—
this is called *not desiring*.
Not desiring, he remains still,
and the world will align itself.

The **Dao**’s action without action,
yet nothing remains undone.

If people of this age
were as inert as logs or stones,
only then could they be called "without action"—
how then could anything be done?

chunks.original_text: 非我所知也。 道德玄经原旨卷之二竟 道德玄经原旨卷之三 教门高士当涂杜道坚注 《经》曰：上德不德，是以有德。 下德不失德，是以无德。 上德无为，而无以为。 下德为之，而有以为。 上仁为之，而无以为。 上义为之，而有以为。 上礼为之，而莫之应，则攘臂而仍之。 故失道而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼。 夫礼者，忠信之薄，而乱之首。 前识者，道之华，而愚之始。 是以大丈夫处其厚，不居其薄。 处其实，不居其华。 故去彼取此。 《原旨》曰：道，蹈也。 德，得也。 蹈道得德，是谓上德。 上德之心，德不己尚，人心自归，是以有德，其德大矣。 下德之心，德不己忘，人心未必归，是以无德，其德小矣。 上德无心於为，无所以为，道之次也。 下德有心於为，有所以为，德斯下矣。 上仁有心於为，无所以为，德之次也。 上义有心於为，有所以为，仁之次也。 上礼有心於为，而人莫之应，义之次也。 人莫力应，则有不肖之心生，有不肖之心生，则攘臂而仍之，不足怪也。 故失道而后德，失德而后化，失化而后义，失义而后礼。 礼者，忠信之薄，而乱之首。 乱则攘臂之作甚矣。 前识者，伯主怀诈，假礼义会盟，以给诸侯，道之华，不实已彰，愚之始。 薄俗已见，是以大丈夫处道德之厚实，不居礼诈之华薄。 故云去彼取此。 噫，皇道降而为帝德，帝德降而为王之仁义，王之仁义降而为伯之智力，智力降而为战国之诈乱，攘臂相仍，民不堪处。 於是玄圣素王者出道德着而理欲分，春秋作而名分定，辞虽不同而旨则一焉。 大丈夫有志当世，致君泽民，要不拘仕隐，修辞立诚，道在其中矣。 《经》曰：昔之得一者，天得一，以清。 地得一，以宁。 神得一，以灵。 谷得一，以盈。 万物得一，以生。 侯王得一，以为天下贞。 其致之，天无以清，将恐裂。 地无以宁，将恐发。 神无以灵，将恐歇。 谷无以盈，将恐竭。 万物无以生，将恐灭。 侯王无以贵高，将恐蹶。 故贵以贱为本，高以下为基，是以侯王自谓孤、寡、不谷，此其以贱为本，非乎。 故致数舆无舆，不欲琭琭如玉，落落如石。 《原旨》曰：道之在天地神物君民间，莫不有分，可自亏不可自盈，是以天亏西北，地缺东南，惟其亏之缺之，而不自满，故能长久。 圣人无全能，其道亦然。 惟无全能，所以为圣也。 为侯王而知此道，故不得不谦以自下，况为臣民，而不知有谦下可乎。 自其大者观之不当无者，众矣。 自其小者观之不当有者，众矣。 既不当有，又不当无，众者可去一，不可去一，道也有分焉。 昔之得一者，如天、地、神、谷、万物、侯王，莫不各得其一，故能以清，以宁，以灵，以盈，以生，以为天下贞。 其致之致极也。 极则天无以清，将恐裂。 地无以宁，将恐发。 神无以灵，将恐歇。 谷无以盈，将恐竭。 万物无以生，将 恐灭。 侯王无以贵高，将恐蹶矣。 无以云者分满则无以自容，其可久乎。 故贵以贱为本，高以下为基。 知分满可戒，故处高贵而不忘贱下，基本固矣。 是以侯王自谓孤、寡、不谷，言其德孤善寡，自谦之辞。 此其以贱为本也，非乎。 自审其辞，而又嗟叹之，故致数舆，无舆，言德贵自隐。 德贵自隐，则在我所得者，众一有表曝之心，则寡矣。

「This is not what I know.

From the original meaning of *Dao De Xuan Jing* (卷之二竟), and the original meaning of *Dao De Xuan Jing* (卷之三):

The Master of the Teachings, **Du Daojian** of Cangtu, annotates:

The *Classic* says:
The **virtue** of the **Way**’s highest does not cling to virtue—
thus, it has **virtue**.

The **virtue** of the **Way**’s lowest does not abandon virtue—
thus, it lacks **virtue**.

The **Way**’s highest acts without action—
yet nothing is left undone.

The **Way**’s lowest acts for action—
yet it has much to do.

The **Way**’s highest **ren** acts with intention—
yet nothing is left undone.

The **Way**’s highest **yi** acts with intention—
yet it has much to do.

The **Way**’s highest **li** acts with intention—
yet none respond in kind,
so it forces arms and persists.

Thus, one loses the **Way** and then finds **virtue**,
loses **virtue** and then finds **ren**,
loses **ren** and then finds **yi**,
loses **yi** and then finds **li**.

For **li** is but the thinnest layer of loyalty and trust,
yet the root of chaos.

Preconceived knowledge is but the superficial bloom of the **Way**,
yet the beginning of folly.

Therefore, the **great man** abides in its depth,
not dwelling in its shallowness.

He holds to its substance,
not lingering on its ornamentation.

Thus, he abandons that and takes this.

The *Original Meaning* says:
The **Way** is to tread.
**Virtue** is to attain.
To tread the **Way** and attain **virtue**—
this is called the **Way**’s highest **virtue**.

The heart of the **Way**’s highest **virtue** does not exalt itself in **virtue**,
so the hearts of people naturally turn to it—
thus, it has **virtue**, and its **virtue** is vast.

The heart of the **Way**’s lowest **virtue** does not forget itself in **virtue**,
so the hearts of people may not necessarily turn to it—
thus, it lacks **virtue**, and its **virtue** is small.

The **Way**’s highest **virtue** has no intention of acting,
no means to act—
this is the **Way**’s secondary aspect.

The **Way**’s lowest **virtue** has intention of acting,
means to act—
thus, its **virtue** is low.

The **Way**’s highest **ren** has intention of acting,
yet no means to act—
this is **virtue**’s secondary aspect.

The **Way**’s highest **yi** has intention of acting,
yet it has means to act—
this is **ren**’s secondary aspect.

The **Way**’s highest **li** has intention of acting,
yet none respond in kind—
this is **yi**’s secondary aspect.

If none respond with strength,
then the heart of the unworthy arises,
and when the heart of the unworthy arises,
it forces arms and persists—
this is not strange.

Thus, one loses the **Way** and then finds **virtue**,
loses **virtue** and then finds **ren**,
loses **ren** and then finds **yi**,
loses **yi** and then finds **li**.

For **li** is but the thinnest layer of loyalty and trust,
yet the root of chaos.
Chaos brings forth much forcing of arms.

Preconceived knowledge is but the **Way**’s superficial bloom,
the **Way**’s lack of substance now revealed,
folly’s beginning.
The shallow customs are already evident—
thus, the **great man** abides in the **Way**’s depth and substance,
not dwelling in the **li**’s superficiality.

Hence, it is said: *abandon that and take this.*

Alas! The **Way** descends to become the **virtue** of the Emperor,
the Emperor’s **virtue** descends to become the **ren** and **yi** of the King,
the King’s **ren** and **yi** descend to become the **yi** and **strategy** of the **Duke**,
the **Duke**’s **strategy** descends to become the deceit and chaos of the Warring States,
forcing arms and persisting—
the people cannot endure it.

Thus, the **Way** of the **Way**’s highest and the **Way**’s lowest is revealed,
and the division of **virtue** and **desire** is established.
The *Spring and Autumn Annals* are composed,
and the distinctions of names are defined—
though the words differ, their meaning is one.

The **great man** with aspirations for his age,
aiming to enlighten the ruler and benefit the people,
need not be bound by office or seclusion—
he refines his words and establishes sincerity,
for the **Way** is within them.

The *Classic* says:
Those of old who attained **Oneness**—
the heavens attained **Oneness**, thus it was clear.
The earth attained **Oneness**, thus it was tranquil.
The **spirit** attained **Oneness**, thus it was responsive.
The **valleys** attained **Oneness**, thus they were full.
All things attained **Oneness**, thus they were born.
The lords and kings attained **Oneness**, thus they became the **acme** of the world.

If they overreach in attaining it—
the heavens, lacking clarity, would fear to split.
The earth, lacking tranquility, would fear to erupt.
The **spirit**, lacking responsiveness, would fear to stagnate.
The **valleys**, lacking fullness, would fear to dry.
All things, lacking birth, would fear to perish.
The lords and kings, lacking nobility, would fear to fall.

Thus, nobility is rooted in humility,
and height is founded on lowliness—
hence, lords and kings call themselves *lonely*, *few*, and *unfilled*—
this is their rooting in humility,
is it not?

Thus, they overreach in attaining **Oneness**,
yet have no **Oneness**—
they do not desire brilliance like jade,
nor aloofness like stone.

The *Original Meaning* says:
The **Way**’s presence among heaven, earth, **spirit**, things, and rulers of the people—
none lack their portion,
yet one can only diminish, not increase it.
Thus, the heavens diminish in the west and north,
the earth lacks in the east and south—
only by their diminishing and lacking,
and not by self-satisfaction,
can they endure long.

The Sage has no absolute power,
and the **Way** is the same.
Only by having no absolute power,
can one be called Sage.

If one understands this **Way** as a lord or king,
one must not fail to practice humility and self-lowering—
how much more so for subjects and commoners,
who do not know of humility and self-lowering!

Observing from the greatest aspect,
one should not cling to what should not be—
many such cases exist.
Observing from the smallest aspect,
one should not abandon what should be—
many such cases exist.

Since neither should be abandoned nor should be clung to,
many things can be diminished, yet not all—
the **Way** also has its portions.

Those of old who attained **Oneness**—
like heaven, earth, **spirit**, **valleys**, all things, and lords and kings—
none failed to attain their portion,
thus they could be clear, tranquil, responsive, full, born,
and become the **acme** of the world.
This is attaining to the extreme.

If they overreach to the extreme—
the heavens, lacking clarity, would fear to split.
The earth, lacking tranquility, would fear to erupt.
The **spirit**, lacking responsiveness, would fear to stagnate.
The **valleys**, lacking fullness, would fear to dry.
All things, lacking birth, would fear to perish.
The lords and kings, lacking nobility, would fear to fall.

If one lacks portions and yet seeks to contain them all,
how can it endure?

Thus, nobility is rooted in humility,
and height is founded on lowliness.
Knowing the danger of overreaching,
one must not forget humility and lowliness when in high and noble positions—
the foundation is thus secure.

Hence, lords and kings call themselves *lonely*, *few*, and *unfilled*—
speaking of their **virtue** being lonely and few,
words of self-humility.
This is their rooting in humility,
is it not?

Reflecting on their own words,
and yet sighing in lamentation,
thus they overreach in attaining **Oneness**,
yet have no **Oneness**—
speaking of **virtue**’s noble self-concealment.
If **virtue**’s noble self-concealment is within what I attain,
then those who have the heart to reveal and flaunt
will be few indeed.»

chunks.original_text: 如舆之为物，本具全体，不可数轮、辕、辐、辙，而求为之舆者，数而求之，则为舆者失矣。 此侯王之道所以不欲琭琭如玉，而自多其德。 又不欲落落如· 石，而以德自少。 既不以少，又不以多，则昔之得一者，自然合分之宜。 合分之宜，安有不长久者乎。 《经》曰：反者道之动，弱者道之用。 天下万物生於有，有生於无。 《原旨》曰：反者道之动，弱者道之用。 上句言体，下句言用。 道之体，用也。 如此，反复也，复其见天地之心也。 道无定体，惟变是体。 动则造化流行，万物生焉。 弱，柔也。 柔弱者，生之徒也。 道无定用，惟化是用。 用则生意发施，万物安焉。 噫嘻，天下万物生於有，有生於无，有也，无也，是何物也耶。 虚化神，神化气，气化形，凡具形气者，皆物。 物必有坏，坏则复归於无，有一不坏者，存是何物也耶。 观其生物者气，则知生气者神，生神者道矣。 夫神性也，气命也，合曰道。 圣人立教，使人修道，各正性命，盖本诸此。 仲尼之尽性至命，反终之谓也。 子思之天命谓性，原始之谓也。 老氏言复命而不言性，此言有生於无，性其在矣。 尝论性者，吾所固有，命者，天之所赋，生之始也。 性不得命，吾无以生。 命不得性，天无以赋。 性与命交相养，而后尽有生之道也。 生之终也。 形亡命复，惟性不亡，与道同久修，此谓之修道。 得此谓之得道。 学道人有不能自究本性，反有问命於人者，是未明性命之正也。 吾得因而申之。 《经》曰：上士闻道，勤而行之。 中士闻道，若存若亡。 下士闻道，大笑之。 不笑，不足以为道。 故建言有之，明道若昧，进道若退，夷道若颣。 上德若谷，大白若辱，广德若不足，建德若偷，质真若渝。 大方无隅，大器晚成，大音希声，大象无形。 道隐无名。 夫惟道，善贷且成。 《原旨》曰：道有情有信，无为无形，可传不可受，可得不可见也。 上士闻道，造其有情有信，而又达其无为无形，故勤而行之。 中士闻道，虽造有情有信，而未达无为无形，故若存若亡。 下士闻道，则二者俱惑，故大笑之。 盖下士天资既浅，又为人欲所汨，天理未明，彼物之有形有为者，尚未之造，况道之无为无形者，岂易达哉。 此下士之不容不笑也。 不笑则不足以见吾道之大矣。 建言，古有之言也。 明道若昧，进道若退，夷道若颣，上德若谷，大白若辱，广德若不足，建德若偷，质真若渝。 斯八者，言道之用。 有若无也。 大方无隅，方无隅，故大。 大器晚成，器晚成，故大。 大音希声，音希声，故大。 大象无形、象无形，故大。 斯四者，言道之体。 一实若虚也。 道隐无名，知而不言，能而不为也。 夫惟道，善贷且成。 惟善贷，故可传。 惟且成，故可得。 然则不可受不可见者，道非外物，故不可以手受而目见，惟在闻道勤行，求其在我者而得之心，当不待受而久将自见也。 《经》曰：道生一，一生二，二生三，三生万物。 万物负阴而抱阳，冲气以为和。 人之所恶，惟孤、寡、不谷，而王公以为称。 故物，或损之而益，益之而损。 人之所教，亦我教之。 强梁者不得其死，吾将以为教父。 《原旨》曰：天地生物之心，无他，有塞吾体，帅吾性，冲和一气而已。
chunks.translated_text:
The Wheel, as an object, inherently possesses a complete form—
it cannot be said to have many spokes, yokes, hubs, or axles,
yet if one seeks to make it a Wheel by counting and demanding these parts,
then the Wheel is lost.

Thus, the Way of lords and kings does not desire
to be polished like jade (*琭琭*),
but rather to multiply their **virtue**.
Nor does it wish to be rugged like a *·* stone (*落落*),
but to diminish themselves through **virtue**.

Neither multiplying nor diminishing,
then the former attainment of **Oneness** naturally aligns with the proper distribution of parts.
When the proper distribution of parts is attained,
how can it not endure?

The *Classic* says:
*"Reversal is the movement of the Dao,
and weakness is its operation.*
All things under heaven are born of **Being**,
and **Being** is born of **Non-Being**."

The *Original Meaning* says:
*"Reversal is the movement of the Dao,
and weakness is its operation.*
The upper sentence speaks of **substance**,
the lower of **operation**.
The substance of the Dao is **operation** itself.
Thus, reversal and return are one—
returning to what reveals the heart of Heaven and Earth.
The Dao has no fixed substance,
only change is its substance.
When it moves, **Transformation** and **Manifestation** flow,
and all things are born.
Weakness is softness.
The soft and weak are the companions of life.
The Dao has no fixed operation,
only **Manifestation** is its operation.
When it operates, the intention of life unfolds and applies itself,
and all things find tranquility.

Ah! All things under heaven are born of **Being**,
and **Being** is born of **Non-Being**—
**Being** and **Non-Being**—
what are they truly?

**Void** transforms into **Spirit**,
**Spirit** transforms into **Qi**,
**Qi** transforms into **Form**—
all that possess **Form** and **Qi** are things.
Things must decay,
and when they decay, they return to **Non-Being**.
If there is **Oneness** that does not decay,
what remains is it?

Observing that **Qi** brings forth things,
one knows that **Spirit** generates **Qi**,
and **Spirit** is born of the Dao.
**Spirit** is nature,
**Qi** is fate—
together, they are called the Dao.
The Sage establishes teaching,
so that people may cultivate the Dao,
each rectifying their nature and fate—
this is rooted in this principle.

Zhongni exhausts nature to reach fate,
speaking of reversal to its end.
Zisii says fate is nature,
speaking of the origin of the beginning.
The Master Lao speaks of returning to fate but not of nature—
this is the saying that **Being** is born of **Non-Being**,
for nature is already present.

I have often discussed nature—
what I inherently possess—
and fate—
what Heaven bestows at the beginning of life.
Nature without fate,
I have no means to live.
Fate without nature,
Heaven has no means to bestow.
Nature and fate mutually nourish each other,
and only then is the Dao of life fully realized.
At the end of life,
when form perishes and fate returns,
only nature does not perish—
it endures with the Dao through long cultivation.
This is called cultivating the Dao.
Attaining this is called attaining the Dao.

Those who study the Dao may fail to examine their own original nature,
yet ask of others about fate—
this is not understanding the proper relationship between nature and fate.
I have obtained this principle and will expound it further.

The *Classic* says:
*"The superior man hears the Dao and diligently practices it.
The middle man hears the Dao and holds it uncertainly, as if it exists or does not.
The inferior man hears the Dao and laughs greatly at it.
If one does not laugh, it is not sufficient to be called the Dao.
Thus, the Sage’s speech is established as **Being**,
yet the Dao is as if in darkness.
Advancing the Dao is like retreating,
leveling the Dao is like obstructing it.
The highest **virtue** is like a valley,
the greatest brightness is like a stain,
the broadest **virtue** is like insufficiency,
the established **virtue** is like theft,
the genuine simplicity is like perversity.
The greatest square has no corners,
the greatest vessel is slow to form,
the greatest sound is rare in tone,
the greatest image is formless.
The Dao is hidden and nameless.
Only the Dao is good at lending itself and yet completing its task."*

The *Original Meaning* says:
*"The Dao has sentiment and trustworthiness,
no action and no form—
it can be transmitted but not received,
it can be attained yet not seen.
The superior man hears the Dao and comprehends its sentiment and trustworthiness,
and also grasps its actionless and formless nature—
thus, he diligently practices it.
The middle man hears the Dao and, though he comprehends its sentiment and trustworthiness,
has yet to grasp its actionless and formless nature—
thus, he holds it uncertainly, as if it exists or does not.
The inferior man hears the Dao and is perplexed by both aspects—
thus, he laughs greatly at it.
Indeed, the inferior man’s innate endowment is shallow,
and he is further drowned by human desires—
Heaven’s principles are not yet clear,
and the things of the world that have form and action,
he has yet to attain—
how much less could he grasp the Dao’s actionless and formless nature?
Thus, the inferior man cannot help but laugh.
If he does not laugh, it is not sufficient to reveal the greatness of my Dao.

Established speech, anciently spoken,
the Dao is as if in darkness,
advancing the Dao is like retreating,
leveling the Dao is like obstructing it,
the highest **virtue** is like a valley,
the greatest brightness is like a stain,
the broadest **virtue** is like insufficiency,
the established **virtue** is like theft,
the genuine simplicity is like perversity.
These eight aspects speak of the Dao’s **operation**—
**Being** as if **Non-Being**.

The greatest square has no corners,
the square has no corners, thus it is greatest.
The greatest vessel is slow to form,
the vessel is slow to form, thus it is greatest.
The greatest sound is rare in tone,
the sound is rare in tone, thus it is greatest.
The greatest image is formless,
the image is formless, thus it is greatest.
These four aspects speak of the Dao’s **substance**—
**reality** as if **void**.

The Dao is hidden and nameless,
known yet unsaid,
capable yet unacted upon.
Only the Dao is good at lending itself and yet completing its task.
Only because it is good at lending itself,
it can be transmitted.
Only because it is yet completing its task,
it can be attained.
Thus, the unattainable and unseen aspects of the Dao—
the Dao is not an external thing,
so it cannot be grasped by the hand or seen by the eye.
Only in hearing the Dao and diligently practicing it,
seeking its presence within oneself,
will one naturally attain it without waiting for reception or prolonged seeking.

The *Classic* says:
*"The Dao gives birth to **Oneness**,
**Oneness** gives birth to the **Two**,
the **Two** gives birth to the **Three**,
and the **Three** gives birth to all things.
All things bear **Yin** while embracing **Yang**,
and the interplay of **Qi** creates harmony.
What people detest are the lonely, few, and unfilled—
yet lords and kings take these as their titles.
Thus, things may be diminished to benefit,
or benefited to diminish.
What people teach is also what I teach.
The strong and rigid do not find their proper death—
I will take this as my teacher’s principle."*

chunks.original_text: 彼造物者之生，生不穷合，此而何哉。 冲和，中和也。 道生一，无极而太极也。 一生二，两仪生焉。 二生三，三才立而万物生也。 是谓三生万物。 万物负阴而抱阳，冲气以为和。 天阳地阴，二气交感，妙合而凝，一点中虚，乃成冲和。 纯粹至精者，为人。 杂橾不正者，为物。 人物赋形，前俯复伛，负阴抱阳之象也。 兼三才而两之者，在我矣。 政中和，天地位，万物育，正斯道也。 呜呼，惟天地，万物父母。 惟人，万物之灵。 直聪明作元后，元后作民父母。 圣人，以父母天地赤子万民为心。 嗟三代之季，各尚智力，争土害民，上失所爱，下民受虐，玄圣体天地生物之心，法造化冲和之德，尚柔弱，戒刚强，以教养天下，故引王公称孤、寡为喻曰：人之所恶，惟孤、寡、不谷，而王公以为称。 则是尚柔弱，而反以孤、寡为我善也。 况其下者，可以智力自尚，而不知刚强为戒乎。 故物或损之而益，益之而损，或之者当天理未定之时，人欲方炽，惟知以智力自尚刚强为胜。 柔者受损，刚者受益。 及乎天理既定，则柔者益，刚者损矣。 人之未闻道者，往往尚智力，骋刚强，又教人以刚强为善，亦犹我之尚中和，守柔弱，教人以柔弱· 为善也。 圣愚之所见，不同天壤如此。 然则强梁者，终不得其正死，是可戒也。 吾将正为教父。 见不贤而内自省，是亦教诲之而已。 修身而不明此，则无以致吾身之中和。 治国而不明此，则无以育天地间之万物。 《经》曰：天下之至柔，驰骋天下之至坚。 无有，入于无间。 吾是以知无为之有益。 不言之教，无为之益，天下希及之。 《原旨》曰：上章发明冲和之德，以戒强梁者不得其死。 此章言至柔之理，以明驰骋天下之至坚。 是皆天道自然之理。 圣人表而出之，以戒天下，非托於空言者也。 何以明之，观天运太虚，今古不息，孰使之然哉，铃有载而运之者矣。 故曰：浮天载地者，气也，水也。 气乃无形之水，水乃有形之气。 水至柔而攻坚，强者莫之能胜。 气至柔而驰骋，至坚者无以加焉。 圣人言至柔而不言气，气其在矣。 天以冲和至柔之气，行乎乾健至刚之体，是天下之至柔，驰骋天下之至坚也。 无有，入於无间。 无有，气也。 气无质，故曰无有。 无间，空虚也。 观无有之气入於太虚空无之间，气无为而四时自行，四时不言而百物自生，益亦广矣。 吾是以知无为之有益。 不言之教，无为之益，天下希及之。 希及之云者，嗟叹之辞也。 圣人体天道而处无为之事，行不言之教，以教天下。 简易明白，宜可信也。 何天下希有信及者乎。 信既不及，其何以行之哉。 圣人固无欲，人必已信之，心然而嗟叹之辞，有不容不发。 此道惟老孔得之，而不得行於当世，故孔子亦有予欲无言之叹。 又曰：如有用我者，五＃其为东周乎。 圣人之忧以天下，以道自任也。 如此是，岂果欲无言哉。 是岂不欲行於当世哉。 必有不得已者，而已之者矣。 《经》曰：名与身，孰亲。 身与货，孰多。 得与亡，孰病。 是故甚爱，必大费。 多藏，必厚亡。 知足，不辱。 知止，不殆。 可以长久。 《原旨》曰：养生全身，所以全吾天也。 养生而不知全身，全身而不知全天，则是刍豢之养矣。 物之具气体于天地间者，莫不有养焉。
chunks.translated_text:
The *Classic* says:
*"That which creates and gives birth does not exhaust itself in merging—
this, then, is what?*
**Succession and harmony** is **the central harmony**.

*The Dao gives birth to **Oneness**,
which is **the Unexcelled** and **the Supreme Unexcelled**.*
**Oneness** gives birth to the **Two**,
and the **Twofold Polarities** arise.
The **Two** gives birth to the **Three**,
and the **Three Powers** are established, giving birth to all things.
This is called **the Three giving birth to all things**.

All things bear **Yin** while embracing **Yang**,
and the interplay of **Qi** creates harmony.
**Heaven is Yang**, **Earth is Yin**—
the **Two Qi** intermingle and resonate,
refining their union to coalesce,
a singular point in the void,
thus forming **succession and harmony**.

The purest and most refined is **the Human**,
the mixed and irregular is **the Material**.
Humans and things receive their forms—
before and after, bowing and stooping—
embodying the **Yin-Yang** pattern.

Those who combine the **Three Powers** yet remain **Twofold** are found in me.
To uphold **central harmony** is to align with **Heaven and Earth**,
to nurture all things is to rectify the **Dao**.

Ah! **Heaven and Earth** are the parents of all things.
**Humans** are the **souls** of all things.
The **Directly Perceptive and Intelligent** act as the **Primordial Sovereign**,
the **Primordial Sovereign** nurtures the people as parents.
The **Sage** takes the **Heaven and Earth’s** nurturing of all things and the **people as their children** as his heart.

Alas, in the **Later Ages of the Three Dynasties**,
each valued **intellect and strength**,
contended for land, harming the people,
the rulers lost what they cherished,
the common folk suffered cruelty.
The **Mysterious Sage** embodied **Heaven and Earth’s** nurturing heart,
following the **Dao’s** **succession and harmony**,
valuing **gentleness and weakness**,
warning against **rigidity and strength**,
to teach and nurture the world.
Thus, he used the **lords and kings’** titles of **lonely, few, and unfilled** as an analogy:
*'What people detest are the lonely, few, and unfilled—
yet lords and kings take these as their titles.'*
This is to uphold **gentleness and weakness**,
yet **lonely, few, and unfilled** are paradoxically my virtues.
How much more so for those below—
who may boast of **intellect and strength**,
yet fail to recognize **rigidity and strength** as warnings?

Thus, things may be diminished to benefit,
or benefited to diminish.
Those who act in **Heaven’s Way** undetermined,
when human desires burn fiercely,
know only to boast of **intellect and strength** as victory.
The **gentle** suffer loss,
the **strong** gain benefit.
But once **Heaven’s Way** is established,
the **gentle** are benefited,
the **strong** are diminished.

Those who have not heard the **Dao**,
often value **intellect and strength**,
flaunt **rigidity and strength**,
and even teach others that **rigidity and strength** are good—
just as I uphold **central harmony**,
guard **gentleness and weakness**,
and teach others that **gentleness and weakness** are good.

The **Sage’s** and the **fool’s** perceptions differ as **Heaven and Earth**.
Yet the **strong and rigid** never meet their proper death—
this is a warning.
I will take this as my teacher’s principle.
To see the unvirtuous and reflect inwardly is also teaching and admonishing.

To cultivate oneself without understanding this is to fail in attaining **my central harmony**.
To govern the realm without understanding this is to fail in nurturing all things between **Heaven and Earth**.

The *Classic* says:
*'The utmost **gentleness** in the world
overcomes the utmost **firmness** in the world.
The **non-existent** enters the **non-gap**.
I know this is the benefit of **non-action**.
The teaching of **non-speech** is the benefit of **non-action**,
few in the world can attain it.'*

The *Original Meaning* says:
*'The previous chapter elucidates the **virtue of succession and harmony**,
to warn the **strong and rigid** that they will not meet their proper death.
This chapter speaks of the **principle of utmost gentleness**,
to illustrate that it overcomes the **utmost firmness** in the world.
These are all **Heaven’s Way** in its natural principles.
The **Sage** presents them clearly,
to warn the world—
not merely relying on empty words.
How can this be proven?
Observe the **Heavenly Movement** in the **Supreme Void**,
ancient and modern, ceaseless—
who compels it thus?
There is a **Bell** that tolls without rest to move it.
Thus it is said:
*The **floating Heaven** and the **bearing Earth** are **Qi**,
and **water**.
**Qi** is the **formless water**,
**water** is the **formed Qi**.
**Water**, though **gentle**, conquers **firmness**—
the **strong** cannot overcome it.
**Qi**, though **gentle**, moves and overcomes—
the **firmest** cannot resist it.
The **Sage** speaks of **utmost gentleness** yet does not mention **Qi**—
**Qi** is surely present.
**Heaven**, with its **succession and harmony** of **utmost gentleness**,
operates through the **dry and firm** body of **the Supreme Unexcelled**—
this is **the utmost gentleness** overcoming **the utmost firmness** in the world.
The **non-existent** enters the **non-gap**.
The **non-existent** is **Qi**.
**Qi** has no substance—
thus it is called **non-existent**.
The **non-gap** is **emptiness**.
Observe how the **non-existent Qi** enters the **Supreme Void’s** emptiness—
**Qi** acts without effort,
yet the four seasons proceed naturally.
The four seasons speak not,
yet all things are born—
its benefits are vast indeed.
Thus I know the benefit of **non-action**.
The teaching of **non-speech** is the benefit of **non-action**,
few in the world can attain it.

The phrase *"few in the world can attain it"* is an exclamation of lament.
The **Sage** embodies **Heaven’s Way**,
yet engages in **non-action** and **non-speech**,
to teach the world.
Simple and clear—
it should be trustworthy.
Yet why are there so few who believe and follow?
If belief does not reach them,
how can they act accordingly?
The **Sage** truly has no desires—
yet if people must be convinced,
the heart naturally laments this phrase,
which cannot be withheld.

This **Dao** was grasped by **Laozi** and **Confucius**,
yet they could not practice it in their age—
thus **Confucius** also had his sigh of *"I wish to speak but cannot."*
Again he said:
*"If there were someone who used me,
would I not make him the **Eastern Zhou**?"*
The **Sage’s** sorrow was for the world,
and he took the **Dao** upon himself.
If this is so,
could it be that he truly wished to speak but could not?
Could it not be that he wished to practice in his age?
There must have been reasons he could not—
and he accepted them.

The *Classic* says:
*'**Name** and **body**—which is closer?
**Body** and **wealth**—which is more?
**Gain** and **loss**—which is more harmful?
Thus, the more one loves,
the greater the expense.
The more one hoards,
the greater the loss.
To know **sufficiency** is to avoid disgrace.
To know **cessation** is to avoid peril.
This can endure long.'*

The *Original Meaning* says:
*'Nurturing life and preserving the body
is how one preserves **Heaven**.
To nurture life without knowing how to preserve the body,
or to preserve the body without knowing how to preserve **Heaven**,
is like feeding livestock.
All things that possess **Qi** and **body** between **Heaven and Earth**,
none lack their own nurturing."*

chunks.original_text: 天之所与，一物一理，小大有分，修短有数，初不待求，而养者未尝不足。 惟不待求，故未见求而得所养，不求不得所养。 使求而得所养，不求不得所养，则是天将容私，欲人之路己。 欲人之路己，则有情者长得所养而不死，无情者不得所养而几乎绝矣。 是何足以言天之至公哉。 惟不待求，故不可求。 此其所以为天也。 何独人而不知察妄，有求益所养之心乎。 苟有求益所养之心，则名之食，货之黩，不亡於此，则亡於彼，反不得全其天之所与养，是可悲也。 圣人悯其不悟而诲之，以名比身，二者孰亲。 以身比货，二者孰多。 以得比亡，二者孰病。 所爱既甚，所费必大。 所藏既多，所亡铃厚。 惟知足而不甚爱，则不致辱之病。 知止而不厚藏，则不致殆之病。 然后可以尽吾养之善，而吾之天者全矣。 是则可以长久也。 为上而知此道，则不待下之求，而不废所与养。 为下而知此道，则不敢上之求，而安吾所自养。 不甚爱，不多藏，知止知足，各全所养，则家可长，国可久矣。 《经》曰：大成若缺，其用不敝。 大盈若冲，其用不穷。 大直若屈，大巧若拙，大辩若讷。 躁胜寒，静胜热，清静为天下正。 《原旨》曰：谦之时义大矣哉。 天道亏盈而益谦，故下济而光明。 大成若缺，其用不敝也。 地道变盈而流谦，故卑而上行。 大盈若冲，其用不穷也。 鬼神害盈而福谦，故尊而光。 大直若屈也。 人道恶盈而好谦，故卑而不可踰。 大巧若拙也。 君子以裒多益寡，称物平施。 大辩若钠也。 躁胜寒，地在山上也。 静胜热，山在地下也。 清静为天下正。 谦亨君子有终万民服也。 噫嘻，《易》、《老》之道，同出异名。 《道德》演於坟、典，《易象》则於图书。 一皆观天道以明人道者也。 上章言名货以戒爱藏，言得亡以明止足，则裒益平施之义可见。 下章言可歌不知足，欲得以戒罪祸，咎谦之义可见。 或曰：胜，极也。 躁极则寒，静极则热，此以气言也。 或曰：躁能胜寒，静能胜热，此以理言也。 谦其在矣。 然则《谦》之六五曰：不富以其邻，利用侵伐。 上六曰鸣谦，利用行师征邑国。 而此下章曰：天下有道，却走马以粪。 天下无道，戎马生於郊。 则谦言侵伐行师，无乃不可乎。 知卑而不可瑜，裒益平施则可也。 若必至戎马生郊，谦何取焉。 老圣之道，以柔胜刚，故与谦合。 申韩不善学，流入刑名，为圣门万世罪人哀哉。 《经》曰：天下有道，却走马以粪。 天下无道，戎马生於郊。 罪莫大於可欲，祸莫大於不知足，咎莫大於欲得。 故知足之足，常足矣。 《原旨》曰：古之有天下者，土地之广，人民之众，君寿之修短，唐虞而上，远不可稽。 见之《禹贡》之辞，则知尧、舜之朝，东渐于海，西被于流沙，朔南暨，声教讫于四海。 人民如其地。 尧为天子，舜、禹、稷、契、咎繇为臣。 荡荡乎民，无能名焉。 形于击壤之歌，则知为有道之世也。 尧未甚老，而逊之舜。 舜遵尧之道，未甚老，而逊之禹。 尧、舜，皆不失天下之尊荣，皆天寿百余龄，而子孙皆不失土地之封，不废烝尝之义。 如二圣人者，可谓知足之足，常足矣。 天下有道，却走马以粪。 唐虞之盛可见。 天下无道，戎马生於郊。 夏商之衰可见。 罪莫大於可欲，甚爱大费也。

The *Classic* speaks:

*"Heaven grants to all things—
each has its own Dao and measure,
great and small, long and short,
not awaiting request,
yet those who nurture are never without sustenance.

Only because it is not awaited by seeking,
does one unseen receive what nourishes,
and when not sought, still not fail to receive what nourishes.
If one seeks and yet receives what nourishes,
or does not seek yet fails to receive what nourishes,
then Heaven would favor the private,
and desire that men obstruct themselves.

If Heaven desires that men obstruct themselves,
then sentient beings would long accumulate what nourishes yet never die,
and the insentient would fail to receive what nourishes, nearly perishing.
How can this be said to reflect Heaven’s utmost fairness?

Only because it is not awaited by seeking,
does one not dare to seek it.
This is how it becomes Heaven.
Why alone does man fail to perceive delusion,
and harbor the heart to seek more sustenance?

If one harbors the heart to seek more sustenance,
then the food of fame and the greed for wealth—
if not lost here, will be lost there,
and in reverse, one fails to preserve Heaven’s granted sustenance.
This is truly pitiable.

The Sage pities those who fail to awaken,
and instructs them:
Compare fame to the body—
which is closer?
Compare the body to wealth—
which is more?
Compare gain to loss—
which is more harmful?
The more one loves,
the greater the expense.
The more one hoards,
the greater the loss.
Only by knowing sufficiency
and not loving excessively,
does one avoid disgrace’s harm.
Knowing cessation
and not hoarding greatly,
does one avoid peril’s harm.
Then one may fulfill the goodness of nurturing,
and Heaven’s granted sustenance will be preserved.
This is how one may endure long.

For the ruler who knows this Dao,
he does not await the people’s seeking,
yet does not neglect what Heaven grants to nourish.
For the subject who knows this Dao,
he does not dare to seek from above,
yet remains content with his own self-nourishment.
Not loving excessively,
not hoarding greatly,
knowing cessation and sufficiency,
each preserving his own sustenance,
then households may endure,
and states may last long.

The *Classic* says:
*'Great completion seems deficient—
its use is not exhausted.
Great fullness seems empty—
its use is not spent.
Great uprightness seems bent—
great skill seems clumsy,
great eloquence seems inarticulate.
Agitation overcomes cold,
stillness overcomes heat,
and serene stillness is the Way’s rectitude for all under Heaven.'*

The *Original Meaning* says:
*'The virtue of humility is vast indeed!
Heaven’s Dao diminishes excess yet benefits humility,
so the lowly are rescued and radiance is clear.
Great completion seems deficient—
its use is not exhausted.
Earth’s Dao transforms excess into flowing humility,
so the lowly ascend upward.
Great fullness seems empty—
its use is not spent.
Ghosts and spirits harm excess yet favor humility,
so the honored are radiant.
Great uprightness seems bent.

Human nature abhors excess yet loves humility,
so the lowly are uncrossable.
Great skill seems clumsy.

The gentleman practices *kǎo* (积) the many and aiding the few,
balancing things with just application.
Great eloquence seems hesitant.

Agitation overcomes cold—
the earth lies above the mountains.
Stillness overcomes heat—
the mountains lie below the earth.
Serene stillness is the Way’s rectitude for all under Heaven.
Humility is the gentleman’s virtue,
and all the people serve it.

Ah! The Dao of the *Book of Changes* and the *Laozi*,
though named differently, springs from the same source.
The *Dao De Jing* unfolds in the mound and classic texts,
the *Yijing* manifests in diagrams and words.
All observe Heaven’s Dao to illuminate human nature.

The previous chapter speaks of fame and wealth
to warn against excessive love and hoarding,
and of gain and loss
to clarify knowing cessation and sufficiency—
thus the meaning of *kǎo* (积), aiding, and balanced application, is evident.

This chapter speaks of those who sing of ‘unknowing sufficiency’,
and desire gain to avoid blame and calamity,
thus the virtue of humility is clear.

Some say: *‘Shèng’* (胜) means ‘extreme’.
Extreme agitation brings cold,
extreme stillness brings heat—
this is speaking of *Qi*.
Some say: Agitation can overcome cold,
stillness can overcome heat—
this is speaking of *Dao*.

Humility is present indeed.
Yet then the *Hexagram of Humility*’s sixth line says:
*'Not enriching oneself with neighbors,
beneficial to use slander to invade and plunder.'*
And the top line says: *‘Resounding humility,
beneficial to use troops to march and conquer states.’*
But this lower chapter says:
*'When the Way prevails under Heaven,
the war-horses are turned back to manure.
When the Way does not prevail under Heaven,
war-horses are born in the suburbs.'*
Then humility’s words of invasion and marching troops—
is this not untenable?

Knowing lowliness yet uncrossable,
*aiding the many and the few* with balanced application—
this is acceptable.
If one must reach the point where war-horses are born in the suburbs,
what need has humility of such?

The Sage’s Dao of the *Laozi* teaches
that softness overcomes hardness,
thus aligning with humility.
Yet Shen Buhai and Han Fei failed to learn well,
descending into legalism and name-schooling,
becoming the wretched offenders of the Sage’s gate for ten thousand ages.

The *Classic* says:
*'When the Way prevails under Heaven,
the war-horses are turned back to manure.
When the Way does not prevail under Heaven,
war-horses are born in the suburbs.
No crime is greater than desiring gain,
no calamity greater than unknowing sufficiency,
no blame greater than coveting what is obtained.'*
Thus, the sufficiency of sufficiency,
is always sufficiency.

The *Original Meaning* says:
*'The ancient rulers of all under Heaven—
the vastness of their lands,
the multitude of their people,
the longevity of their sovereigns—
from Yao and Shun onward,
too distant to trace.
Yet in the words of the *Yugong*,
we see that Yao’s and Shun’s reigns
eastward reached the sea,
westward extended to the flowing sands,
northward to the boundless frontier,
and their teachings spread to all four seas.
Their people matched their lands.

Yao ruled as Son of Heaven,
Shun, Yu, Ji, Xie, and Gao Yao as ministers.
They swayed the people with ease—
none could name their virtue.
Manifest in the *Strike-the-Earth* song,
we know them as the age of the Way’s prevalence.
Yao was not yet very old,
yet he yielded the throne to Shun.
Shun followed Yao’s Dao,
not yet very old,
yet he yielded the throne to Yu.
Yao and Shun,
though not losing Heaven’s honor and eminence,
both lived over a hundred years,
and their descendants did not lose their lands’ boundaries,
nor abandon the duty of ancestral sacrifices.
Such as the two Sages,
can truly be called sufficiency’s sufficiency—
always sufficiency.

When the Way prevails under Heaven,
the war-horses are turned back to manure—
the prosperity of Tang and Yu is evident.
When the Way does not prevail under Heaven,
war-horses are born in the suburbs—
the decline of Xia and Shang is evident.
No crime is greater than desiring gain—
excessive love brings great expense.'*

chunks.original_text: 祸莫大於不知足，多藏厚亡也。 咎莫大於欲得，我所欲得，人亦欲得，天下胡为不争，戎马胡为不生。 如恶无道，以就有道，莫若不为夏商之衰，求为唐虞之盛，知足常足，将不失尧、舜之尊荣。 然则天下有道云者，必得君如尧、舜，臣如咎、夔，民如唐虞之民，则比屋可封，人人皆知天下之重，而不以害其生。 孰有可欲之罪，不知足之祸，欲得之咎者哉。 《经》曰：不出户，知天下。 不窥牖，见天道。 其出弥远，其知弥少。 是以圣人不行而知，不见而名，不为而成。 《原旨》曰：不出户，知天下。 为有道圣人言也。 得不为尧让许由者言乎。 不窥牖，见天道。 由辞尧让曰：日月出矣，时雨降矣，爝火之光，灌溉之泽，不亦难且劳乎。 由之不出箕山，所以知天下。 既已治也，出弥远而知弥少，为不知足止者，道不行而知，由之所以不复代尧也。 不见而名，吾将为名乎。 吾将为宾乎。 无为而成，吾无所用天下为。 由不受尧让，是不出户而成万世之名，殆贤於尧矣。 巢父之牛，不饮洗耳之水，是不窥牖而无是非之名，又贤於由矣。 尧授舜，舜授禹。 尧、舜有道有位之圣人，巢、由有道无位之圣人。 如巢、由者，可谓无功名而功名，则是无为而成者也。 庄子与惠子观鱼於濠上。 庄子曰：绦鱼出游从容，是鱼乐也。 惠子曰… 子非鱼，安知鱼之乐。 曰：吾知之濠上矣。 濠梁之水深，网罟不到，鱼不待出濠梁。 而知天下之水，不免有网罟之害，故乐其从容，而不出。 鱼之不出濠梁，是巢、由之不出箕山也。 噫，微后王无以见尧、舜之圣，微尧、舜无以见巢、由之高。 《经》曰：为学日益，为道日损。 损之容又损，以至於无为，无为而无不为。 取天下，常以无事。 及其有事，不足以取天下。 《原旨》曰：为学曰益，众人之道也。 为道曰损，圣人之道也。 上知不能无人心，下愚不能无道心。 若尧授舜曰：允执厥中，又何损焉。 舜授禹加以人心、道心、危微之言，则损之所不免也。 损之又损，以至於无为，无为而无不为。 损之云者损去人欲也。 又损云者人欲去得净尽也。 人欲净尽，则无徇己之为。 无徇己之为，则凡所为者皆天理之所当为，而不可不为也。 如禹之治水，三过其门而不入，劳可见矣。 而曰行其所无事，于以见禹之为，皆所当为而不可不为者也。 取天下，常以无事。 取之云者，非取天下之土地、子女也。 非取天下之犬马、玉帛也。 乐取诸人以为善也。 无事云者，行其所无事也。 惟能乐取诸人以为善，而行其所无事，则天下归之，犹水之就下也。 及其有事，则不足以取天下。 有事云者，谓人莫己若而欲强人之从己也。 强人之从己，众人之道也。 乌足以取天下哉。 《书》曰：罔违道以干百姓之誉，罔佛百姓以从己之欲。 斯言得之矣。 《经》曰：圣人无常心，以百姓心为心。 善者吾善之，不善者吾亦善之，德善。 信者吾信之，不信者吾亦信之，德信。 圣人在天下惵惵，为天下浑其心。 百姓皆注其耳目，圣人皆孩之。 《原旨》曰：圣人应物不先物，故无常心。 此承上章之旨状，其成德言道可常，心不可常。 道常则所应皆理，心常则应不免欲，是未到圣人地也。 圣人之心，太空无云，止水无波，鱼跃鸢飞，物无不应，故能民同胞物，吾与上下与天地同流，一以百姓之心为心。
chunks.translated_text:
Misfortune knows no greater than the failure to know sufficiency—
excessive hoarding brings swift ruin.

No fault is greater than the desire to possess—
what I desire to possess, others also desire to possess.
Why then would the world not contend?
Why would war-horses not multiply?

To flee what is without the Way
and seek what is with the Way,
is better than enduring the decline of Xia and Shang,
and striving for the prosperity of Tang and Yu.
To know sufficiency is to always suffice—
thus one will not lose the eminence of Yao and Shun.

Yet if the Way prevails under Heaven,
it must have rulers like Yao and Shun,
ministers like Gao Yao and Kui,
and people like those of Tang and Yu—
then every household may be ennobled,
and all will recognize the weight of the world,
without harming their own lives.

Who then would bear the guilt of desire,
the calamity of insatiability,
the fault of covetousness?

The *Classic* says:
Without leaving one’s door, one knows the world.
Without peering through a window, one sees the Way of Heaven.
The farther one goes, the less one knows.

Thus the Sage acts without knowing,
names without seeing,
accomplishes without doing.

The *Original Meaning* says:
Without leaving one’s door, one knows the world—
this is the speech of the Sage who follows the Way.
Who else but Yu and Yi refused Yao’s abdication?

Without peering through a window, one sees the Way of Heaven—
Yu declined Yao’s throne, saying:
“The sun and moon have risen,
timely rains descend,
the glow of torches and the nourishment of irrigation—
are they not difficult and laborious?”

Yu’s refusal to descend from Mount Ji,
this was how he knew the world.
Once order is established,
the farther one goes, the less one knows—
this is the fate of those who stop at insatiability.
The Way does not prevail, yet they know—
this is why Yu did not succeed Yao.

“To name without seeing”—
shall I seek fame?
Or shall I be a guest?

“To accomplish without doing”—
I have no need of the world’s affairs.

Yu’s refusal of Yao’s abdication
was to achieve eternal renown without leaving his door—
perhaps he was even more virtuous than Yao.

The cow of Chu Fu
would not drink from the Washui River—
this was to bear no name of right or wrong without peering through a window,
and thus surpass even Yu.

Yao passed the Mandate to Shun,
Shun to Yu.
Yao and Shun were Sages with both the Way and position,
Chu Fu and Yu were Sages with the Way but without position.
Those like Chu Fu and Yu
can be said to have no fame yet achieve fame—
this is to accomplish without doing.

Zhuangzi and Huizi observed fish by the Hao Pond.
Zhuangzi said:
“The carp glides leisurely—
this fish is joyful.”

Huizi said:
“You are not a fish—
how do you know the fish is joyful?”

Zhuangzi replied:
“I know it at the Hao Pond.
The waters of the Hao are deep,
nets cannot reach them,
and the fish do not need to leap from the pond.
Yet I know that in all the world’s waters,
there are still nets that harm them.
Thus they rejoice in their leisure,
and do not emerge.”

The fish’s refusal to leap from the Hao Pond
is like Chu Fu and Yu’s refusal to descend from Mount Ji.

Alas! Without the Later Kings,
we could not see the Sagehood of Yao and Shun.
Without Yao and Shun,
we could not see the exalted virtue of Chu Fu and Yu.

The *Classic* says:
To study is to daily increase,
to follow the Way is to daily decrease.
Decrease until it is empty,
until there is no doing—
no doing, yet nothing remains undone.
To take the world,
one must act with non-action.
When action arises,
it is insufficient to take the world.

The *Original Meaning* says:
To study is to increase—
this is the way of the common people.
To follow the Way is to decrease—
this is the way of the Sage.

The wise cannot lack human-heartedness,
the foolish cannot lack Dao-heartedness.
When Yao entrusted the Mandate to Shun, he said:
“Hold fast to the Mean—
what more could be subtracted?”

When Shun entrusted the Mandate to Yu,
he added words of human-heartedness, Dao-heartedness, and perilous subtlety—
this was what could not be avoided in decreasing.

To decrease again and again,
until there is no doing—
no doing, yet nothing remains undone.
“Decrease” means to remove human desires.
“Decrease again” means to purge human desires utterly.
When human desires are purged,
there is no indulging in self.
Without indulging in self,
all that is done is what Heaven’s principle demands,
and cannot but be done.

As Yu’s flood control—
passing his door three times without entering—
his labor is evident.
Yet he said, *“Act in what is without doing,”*
thus revealing that all Yu did
was what must be done and could not be avoided.

“To take the world” means not to take
the world’s lands and people,
its dogs and horses, its jade and silk.
It means to take joy in what others deem good.
“Without doing” means to act in what is without doing.
Only by taking joy in what others deem good
and acting in what is without doing
will the world rally to you,
as water flows downward.

When action arises,
it is insufficient to take the world.
“Action” means forcing others to follow you
because you believe none are your equal—
this is the way of the common people.
How could it suffice to take the world?

The *Book of Documents* says:
Do not deviate from the Way to seek the people’s praise,
nor deceive the people to satisfy your desires.
These words are well taken.

The *Classic* says:
The Sage has no fixed heart,
but takes the hearts of the people as heart.
The good, I make good;
the ungood, I also make good—virtue is good.
The trustworthy, I trust;
the untrustworthy, I also trust—virtue is trust.
The Sage moves through the world with solemnity,
harmonizing the hearts of the people.
The people all focus their ears and eyes,
while the Sage treats them like infants.

The *Original Meaning* says:
The Sage responds to things without being preceded by them,
thus having no fixed heart.
This follows the meaning of the previous chapter:
virtue and the Way can be constant,
but the heart cannot be constant.
The heart of the Sage is vast as the sky without clouds,
still as water without ripples.
Fish leap, kites fly—
nothing escapes its response.
Thus the Sage unifies all things,
and flows with the high and low,
harmonizing with Heaven and Earth,
taking the hearts of the people as heart.

chunks.original_text: 以百姓之心为心，则物无件者，应之以理而已。 善者，吾应之以善，不善者，吾亦应之以善，德善。 信者，吾应之以信，不信者，吾亦应之以信，德信。 德无常师，主善为师，是以天下之善为善，人无有不善也。 以天下之信为信，人无有不信也。 圣人在天下惵惵，为天下浑其心。 言有位之圣人，如帝尧之在宥天下也。 舜告禹曰：稽于众，舍己从人，不虐无告，不废困穷，惟帝时克，则惵惵浑其心，於焉见矣。 百姓皆注其耳目，天视民视，天听民听，德化流行，人心所归，圣人皆孩之。 一以赤子而视之也。 若夫啮缺之为人，可以为众父，而不可以为众父父者，则去帝尧之一问焉耳。 《经》曰：出生入死，生之徒十有三，死之徒十有三。 人之生，动之死地，亦十有三。 夫何故，以其生生之厚。 盖闻善摄生者，陆行不遇兕虎，入军不被甲兵。 兕无所投其角，虎无所措其爪，兵无所容其刃。 夫何故，以其无死地。 《原旨》曰：品物之盈天地间，莫不有族有祖。 族言其众，祖言其亲。 天地万物之大连庐也。 出生入死，生则有死，死则有生，天理之常，何容心焉。 知吾之出者入者，未尝生，未尝死，则其生之徒者谁乎，死之徒者谁乎，之生之死者又其谁乎。 生十有三，死十有三，之生之死十有三，是九也。 彼何物者耶。 道之为物十，三才各得其三，其一则太极之祖也。 生之徒天三阳，轻清之气，日月星辰之徒也。 死之徒地三阴，重浊之气，山川草木之徒也。 之生之死人三元，冲和之气，精气神也。 人之为人，莫不兼是三才者，而又抱太极之祖，乃有其生，孟轲所谓万物皆备於我者，人亦贵矣。 既得其生，乃不自贵。 养吾之祖而亲者，而乃动之死地，是可哀也。 夫何故，以其忘吾之所自贵，反有过求外物，益其厚养之心，是之谓生生之厚，计亦左矣。 一有心於此，则探虎穴，蹈白刃，不顾危亡，无不为已。 盖闻善摄生者，陆行不遇兕虎，无探穴之心也。 入军不被甲兵，无蹈刃之心也。 兕何从而投其角，虎何从而措其爪，兵何从而容其刃。 夫何故，以其吾无致死之地，物亦无伤焉。 《经》曰：道生之，德畜之，物形之，势成之。 是以万物莫不尊道而贵德。 道之尊，德之贵，夫莫之爵，而常自然。 故道生之，畜之，长之，育之，成之，熟之，养之，覆之。 生而不有，为而不恃，长而不宰，是谓玄德。 《原旨》曰：道生，德畜，物形，势成，此承上章之旨。 言天地庶物，皆道气所生。 道，物之祖也。 众妙在焉。 其为物不贰，生物不测者乎。 德，物之族也。 一之未形者，在焉。 含畜功至，物得以形势，一之既形者，物各成其态也。 势成则貌象，声色具焉。 大而天之穹窿，地之磅砖，微而食酰朝菌之化，蜩甲蛇蜕之假，一皆祖族道德而为物者也。 是以万物莫不尊道而贵德。 道之尊，德之贵，莫之爵，而常自然。 谓之族，谓之祖，则是子天地而孙万物也。 又谁爵焉。 道德之常自然而已。 故曰：生之，畜之，长之，育之，成之，熟之，养之，覆之。 生而不有，为而不恃，长而不宰，是谓玄德。 圣人体道为心，曲成万物，而不宰其德玄矣。 舜之玄德升闻，亦此道也。 《经》曰：天下有始，以为天下母。 既得其母，以知其子。
chunks.translated_text:
With the hearts of the people as my own,
then there is nothing that does not respond naturally—
I simply respond to it with the Way.

The virtuous, I respond to with virtue—
the unvirtuous, I also respond to with virtue—**virtue is virtue**.
The trustworthy, I respond to with trust—
the untrustworthy, I also respond to with trust—**virtue is trust**.

Virtue has no constant teacher,
but takes virtue itself as its teacher.
Thus, all virtue under Heaven is virtue,
and no one fails to be virtuous.

With trust as the trust of all under Heaven,
no one fails to be trustworthy.

The Sage moves through the world with solemnity,
harmonizing the hearts of all people.
The Sage with **positioned speech**—
like **Emperor Yao** in his **tolerant governance** of all.

**Shun told Yu**:
*"Consult the multitude,
abandon self to follow others,
do not oppress the helpless,
do not neglect the poor and destitute.
Only when the **Emperor’s timing** is perfect,
does solemnity and harmonization of hearts appear."*

The people all focus their ears and eyes,
while Heaven sees as the people see,
Heaven hears as the people hear—
virtue and transformation spread,
where hearts naturally turn.
The Sage treats them all as infants—
**one regards them with the eyes of a赤子 (*baby/innocent child*).**

As for **啮缺 (*Niè Kuē*)**, though he could be the father of the multitude,
he could not be the father of the multitude’s father—
he was but a single step removed from **Emperor Yao**.

The *Classic* says:
*"To be born and enter death,
those who belong to life are thirteen in ten,
those who belong to death are thirteen in ten.
Humans who live,
thirteen in ten move toward death’s domain.
Why is this so?
Because of the **thick nourishment of life**.*

I have heard that those who skillfully **cultivate life (*shè shēng*)***
walk on land and do not meet **兕 (*rú*)** or tigers,
enter armies and are not struck by weapons or soldiers.
**兕 (*rú*)** have nowhere to lodge their horns,
tigers have nowhere to place their claws,
soldiers have nowhere to wield their blades.
Why is this so?
Because there is no **death’s domain** for them.

The *Original Meaning* says:
*"All things under Heaven and Earth,
none do not have **clans** and **ancestors**.
**Clans** refer to their multitude,
**ancestors** refer to their intimacy.
This is the great **连庐 (*lián lú*)** of Heaven and Earth and all things.
To be born and enter death—
life brings death,
death brings life—
this is the constant principle of Heaven.
How could the heart interfere with it?

Knowing my **出 (*chū*)** and **入 (*rù*)**—
never having been born,
never having died—
then who are those who belong to life?
Who are those who belong to death?
And who are those who belong to neither life nor death?

Life is thirteen in ten,
death is thirteen in ten,
neither life nor death is thirteen in ten—
this makes nine.
What kind of thing is this?

The **Dao** is tenfold,
the **三才 (*Three Powers*)** each take their three,
and the remaining one is the **祖 (*ancestor*)** of **太极 (*Tàijí*)**.
Those who belong to life are the **天三阳 (*Heaven’s Three Yang*)**—
light and clear **气 (*qi*)**, the kin of the sun, moon, and stars.
Those who belong to death are the **地三阴 (*Earth’s Three Yin*)**—
heavy and turbid **气 (*qi*)**, the kin of mountains, rivers, grasses, and trees.
Those who belong to neither life nor death are the **人三元 (*Human’s Three Elements*)**—
**冲和 (*chōng hé*)** **气 (*qi*)**, the kin of **精 (*jing*)**, **气 (*qi*)**, and **神 (*shén*)**.

Humans as humans,
none do not combine these **Three Powers**,
while also embracing the **祖 (*ancestor*)** of **太极 (*Tàijí*)**,
thus attaining their life.
This is what **Mencius** called:
*'All things are complete within me'*—
humans are thus noble as well.

Having attained their life,
they do not regard it as their own.
Those who **nourish their ancestor** while being intimate,
yet **move toward death’s domain**—
this is truly pitiful.

Why is this so?
Because they forget their own source of nobility,
yet seek externally to add to their nourishment,
increasing their **thick nourishment of life**.
This is called **calculating on the left**—
once the heart is set upon this,
they will **enter tiger’s dens** and **tread upon white blades**,
unmindful of peril and ruin,
and none will refrain.

I have heard that those who skillfully **cultivate life (*shè shēng*)***
walk on land and do not meet **兕 (*rú*)** or tigers—
they have no **心 (*heart*)** of entering dens.
Enter armies and are not struck by weapons or soldiers—
they have no **心 (*heart*)** of treading blades.
From where does **兕 (*rú*)** come to lodge its horns?
From where does the tiger come to place its claws?
From where do soldiers come to wield their blades?
Why is this so?
Because I have no **death’s domain**,
and thus nothing can harm me.

The *Classic* says:
*"The Dao **gives birth** to it,
**virtue** **nurtures** it,
things **take form** from it,
**势 (*shì*)** **completes** it.
Thus all things do not fail to **revere the Dao** and **honor virtue**.
The Dao’s reverence, virtue’s honor—
none bestow titles upon it,
yet it remains ever naturally so.
Hence the Dao **gives birth**, **nurtures**, **lengthens**, **rears**, **completes**, **ripens**, **nourishes**, and **covers**.
It **gives birth** yet does not possess,
**acts** yet does not rely,
**lengthens** yet does not control—
this is called **玄德 (*Xuán Dé*)** **virtue/power**."*

The *Original Meaning* says:
*"The Dao gives birth,
virtue nurtures,
things take form,
**势 (*shì*)** completes—
this follows the meaning of the previous chapter.
It speaks of Heaven and Earth and all things,
all born from **Dao/Way** **气 (*qi*)**.
The Dao is the **祖 (*ancestor*)** of things—
all marvels are within it.
Its **形 (*form*)** is singular,
its **生 (*birth*)** is boundless.

Virtue is the **族 (*clan*)** of things—
its **一 (*oneness*)** is in the unformed.
When **nurturing** reaches its peak,
things attain their **形 (*form*)** and **势 (*shì*)**—
its **一 (*oneness*)** is in the formed,
and things each **complete their appearance**.

When **势 (*shì*)** is completed,
their **貌 (*appearance*)** and **象 (*form*)** are manifest,
their **声 (*sound*)** and **色 (*color*)** are present.
The grand—Heaven’s **穹窿 (*qióng lóng*)** dome,
Earth’s **磅砖 (*páng zhèn*)** vastness—
the minute—**朝菌 (*zhāo jūn*)**’s transformation,
**蜩 (*tiáo*)**’s shell and **蛇 (*snake*)**’s slough—
all are **祖 (*ancestors*)**, **族 (*clans*)**, and **道 (*Dao*)** **德 (*virtue*)** becoming things.

Thus all things do not fail to **revere the Dao** and **honor virtue**.
The Dao’s reverence, virtue’s honor—
none bestow titles upon it,
yet it remains ever naturally so.
Saying it is **族 (*clan*)**, saying it is **祖 (*ancestor*)**—
this is to be **子 (*son*)** of Heaven and Earth,
and **孙 (*grandson*)** of all things.
Who then bestows titles?
Virtue and the Way are constant and natural.
Hence it is said:
**'The Dao gives birth, nurtures, lengthens, rears, completes, ripens, nourishes, and covers.
It gives birth yet does not possess,
acts yet does not rely,
lengthens yet does not control—
this is called **玄德 (*Xuán Dé*)** **virtue/power**.'***

The Sage embodies the Dao as his heart,
**completing** all things,
yet does not **控 (*control*)** their **玄德 (*Xuán Dé*)** **virtue/power**—
this is the **玄德 (*Xuán Dé*)** of the Sage.
**Shun’s** **玄德 (*Xuán Dé*)** **virtue/power** ascending and heard,
is also this Dao.

The *Classic* says:
*"Heaven and Earth have their beginning,
and it is called the **mother** of Heaven and Earth.
Having obtained their mother,
one knows their children."*
